facts.text: A day on Venus is longer than a year on Venus—it takes 243 Earth days for Venus to rotate once on its axis, but only 225 Earth days to orbit the Sun.
facts.verification_note: Venus's sidereal rotation period is indeed 243 Earth days while its orbital period is 225 Earth days, making its day longer than its year.
facts.image_description: The illustration shows Venus in a split-screen composition against the black velvet of space: on the left, a slow-motion sequence of the planet rotating on its tilted axis with glowing arc trails marking its 243-day rotation in deep amber and gold; on the right, the same planet zipping along its orbital path around a brilliant Sun with swift, silvery-blue motion trails completing its 225-day journey. The style blends scientific diagram with dynamic motion graphics, featuring a luminous, sulfuric-yellow Venus with swirling cloud patterns, while elegant numerical labels (243 and 225) float in crisp white text alongside clock-face graphics that emphasize the paradox. The Sun blazes in the background with corona flares in orange and white, and subtle grid lines mark the orbital plane, creating a sense of cosmic clockwork where time moves backward.

facts.text: Tardigrades, microscopic animals also known as water bears, can survive being frozen to near absolute zero (-272°C), heated to 150°C, exposed to the vacuum of space, and blasted with radiation doses 1,000 times higher than what would kill a human. When conditions become unbearable, they expel almost all water from their bodies and enter a death-like state called cryptobiosis, where they can remain for decades before springing back to life when rehydrated.
facts.verification_note: All stated claims are well-documented in scientific literature, including tardigrades' survival of extreme temperatures (near absolute zero to 150°C), space vacuum exposure, high radiation tolerance (up to 5,000-6,000 Gy vs. ~5-10 Gy lethal to humans), and their ability to enter cryptobiosis for extended periods through desiccation.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a magnified tardigrade as the central subject, rendered in a semi-translucent, crystalline form against a split-screen cosmic background. On one half, show the tardigrade surrounded by swirling frost crystals and deep blue-purple hues representing extreme cold, while the other half glows with intense orange-red heat waves and visible radiation particles illustrated as golden streaks. The tardigrade itself should be shown in meticulous scientific detail with its eight stubby legs and clawed feet clearly visible, its body appearing both vulnerable and indestructible—perhaps with one half showing its normal hydrated state in soft peachy-browns and the other half in its desiccated cryptobiotic state rendered in pale, almost ghostly whites and grays. The background should incorporate subtle elements of space (distant stars, nebulae) and extreme environments, with dramatic lighting that makes the tiny creature appear heroic and otherworldly, using a style that blends scientific accuracy with surreal, almost mythological grandeur.

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory and prevent the droppings from rolling away. Scientists discovered this happens because wombat intestines have varying elasticity in different sections, with stiff and soft areas that mold the poop into cubes during the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2018-2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces through varying intestinal elasticity in the final portion of digestion, and they do stack these droppings to mark territory on rocks and logs where round feces would roll off.
facts.image_description: A scientifically-styled cross-section illustration showing a wombat in profile with a transparent view of its intestinal system, rendered in warm earth tones against a soft twilight backdrop. The intestines are depicted with color-coded regions—stiff sections in deep burgundy and elastic sections in soft pink—with magnified circular insets showing the geometric transformation of waste from cylindrical to cubic shapes during the final digestive stage. In the foreground, a stack of precisely-formed, caramel-brown cubic droppings sits atop a mossy rock, catching golden-hour lighting that emphasizes their sharp edges and unusual geometry. The style blends medical illustration precision with nature documentary aesthetics, using cutaway techniques and subtle arrows to guide the viewer through the 8% digestive journey where the remarkable cube formation occurs.

    <!-- Intestine elastic section -->

  <!-- Cube shape in cross-section -->

  <rect x="470" y="355" width="8" height="15" fill="#f4a6b8" opacity="0.8" rx="2"/>
  
  <!-- Connector line to final intestine -->

    <polygon points="15,-10 15,10 20,5 20,-15" fill="#8b6849"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Top cube -->
  <g transform="translate(600, 430)">
    <polygon points="-15,-10 15,-10 15,10 -15,10" fill="url(#cubeGradient)"/>

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory and prevent the droppings from rolling away. Scientists discovered this happens because wombat intestines have varying elasticity in different regions, with stiff and soft sections that mold the poop into cubes during the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to varying elasticity in their intestinal walls during the final portion of digestion, and they do use these distinctive droppings to mark territory on elevated surfaces where the cubic shape prevents rolling.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional scientific diagram in a semi-transparent, educational style showing a wombat's digestive tract in soft pinks and amber tones, with the final portion of the intestine highlighted to reveal alternating bands of deep rose (stiff sections) and pale cream (elastic sections) that gradually transform round fecal matter into distinct cubes. In the foreground, a photorealistic wombat is shown in its natural Australian bush habitat at golden-hour lighting, carefully stacking dark brown, perfectly geometric cube-shaped droppings on a rock or log, with some cubes already arranged in a small pyramid. The background should feature eucalyptus trees and native grasses in muted greens and browns, while an inset magnified view shows the microscopic detail of how the intestinal walls compress and mold the material into sharp 90-degree angles. The overall style should blend veterinary textbook precision with the warmth of nature documentary photography, using a color palette of earthy browns, soft tissue pinks, and natural bush greens.

Scientists discovered this happens because the intestines have varying elasticity at different points, with stiffer regions at the cube edges and more flexible sections at the faces, essentially molding the poop into cubes during the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces through varying intestinal elasticity in the final portion of digestion, and they do use these distinctive droppings to mark territory on elevated surfaces where the cubic shape prevents rolling.
facts.image_description: The illustration should be a split-panel scientific diagram with warm, earthy tones. The left panel shows a cross-sectional view of a wombat's intestinal tract in soft pinks and purples, with color-coded regions highlighting the varying elasticity—stiffer areas marked in deep burgundy at the corners and more flexible zones in lighter coral along the flat surfaces, with arrows indicating the directional pressure that forms the cubic shape. The right panel depicts a photorealistic wombat in golden afternoon light, positioned beside a small stack of its distinctive cube-shaped droppings on a mossy rock, with the cubes rendered in rich browns showing their precise geometric edges and slightly textured surfaces. A subtle transparent overlay connects the two panels, showing ghosted cubic forms emerging from the intestinal pathway to the final stacked product, creating an elegant visual flow that bridges internal biology with external behavior.

    <linearGradient id="flexibleRegion" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ff9a7a;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ffb89d;stop-opacity:0.8" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="wombatFur" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#8b7355;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#6b5744;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#4a3f2f;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="cubeGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#5c4033;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#7a5c4d;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#4a3228;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="sunlight" cx="70%" cy="20%" r="60%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffd89b;stop-opacity:0.6" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ffd89b;stop-opacity:0" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <filter id="shadow">
      <feGaussianBlur in="SourceAlpha" stdDeviation="3"/>
      <feOffset dx="2" dy="2" result="offsetblur"/>
      <feComponentTransfer>
        <feFuncA type="linear" slope="0.3"/>
      </feComponentTransfer>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- Background -->
  <rect width="800" height="600" fill="url(#bgGradient)"/>
  
  <!-- Left Panel - Intestinal Cross-section -->
  <g id="leftPanel">
    <!-- Panel background -->
    <rect x="20" y="50" width="360" height="500" fill="#f9f4ef" rx="10" opacity="0.7"/>
    
    <!-- Intestinal tract pathway -->
    <path d="M 100 100 Q 150 120 180 160 T 200 240 Q 210 300 220 360 T 240 480" 
          stroke="url(#intestineBase)" stroke-width="80" fill="none" opacity="0.6"/>
    
    <!-- Cross-section view -->
    <ellipse cx="200" cy="300" rx="90" ry="85" fill="url(#intestineBase)" filter="url(#shadow)"/>
    
    <!-- Stiff regions (corners) -->
    <path d="M 130 250 Q 125 245 130 240 L 145 245 Z" fill="url(#stiffRegion)"/>
    <path d="M 270 250 Q 275 245 270 240 L 255 245 Z" fill="url(#stiffRegion)"/>
    <path d="M 130 350 Q 125 355 130 360 L 145 355 Z" fill="url(#stiffRegion)"/>
    <path d="M 270 350 Q 275 355 270 360 L 255 355 Z" fill="url(#stiffRegion)"/>
    
    <!-- Stiff corner indicators -->
    <rect x="135" y="245" width="20" height="20" fill="url(#stiffRegion)" opacity="0.9"/>
    <rect x="245" y="245" width="20" height="20" fill="url(#stiffRegion)" opacity="0.9"/>
    <rect x="135" y="335" width="20" height="20" fill="url(#stiffRegion)" opacity="0.9"/>
    <rect x="245" y="335" width="20" height="20" fill="url(#stiffRegion)" opacity="0.9"/>
    
    <!-- Flexible regions (faces) -->
    <rect x="160" y="250" width="80" height="15" fill="url(#flexibleRegion)" opacity="0.9"/>
    <rect x="160" y="335" width="80" height="15" fill="url(#flexibleRegion)" opacity="0.9"/>
    <rect x="140" y="270" width="15" height="60" fill="url(#flexibleRegion)" opacity="0.9"/>
    <rect x="245" y="270" width="15" height="60" fill="url(#flexibleRegion)" opacity="0.9"/>
    
    <!-- Pressure arrows -->
    <path d="M 200 220 L 200 250" stroke="#8b2f47" stroke-width="3" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
    <path d="M 200 380 L 200 350" stroke="#8b2f47" stroke-width="3" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
    <path d="M 110 300 L 140 300" stroke="#8b2f47" stroke-width="3" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
    <path d="M 290 300 L 260 300" stroke="#8b2f47" stroke-width="3" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
    
    <!-- Cube formation indicator -->
    <rect x="175" y="420" width="50" height="50" fill="#8b6f47" opacity="0.6" stroke="#5c4033" stroke-width="2"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Arrow markers -->
  <defs>
    <marker id="arrowhead" markerWidth="10" markerHeight="10" refX="9" refY="3" orient="auto">
      <polygon points="0 0, 10 3, 0 6" fill="#8b2f47"/>

  </defs>
  
  <!-- Connecting overlay -->

    <rect x="380" y="435" width="28" height="28" fill="#8b6f47" opacity="0.4"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Right Panel - Wombat and Droppings -->
  <g id="rightPanel">
    <!-- Panel background -->
    <rect x="420" y="50" width="360" height="500" fill="#e8dcc8" rx="10" opacity="0.5"/>
    
    <!-- Sunlight effect -->
    <ellipse cx="650" cy="150" rx="120" ry="100" fill="url(#sunlight)"/>
    
    <!-- Mossy rock -->
    <ellipse cx="650" cy="480" rx="140" ry="50" fill="#5a6b4a" opacity="0.7"/>
    <ellipse cx="650" cy="475" rx="130" ry="45" fill="#6b7c5a" opacity="0.8"/>
    <ellipse cx="650" cy="470" rx="120" ry="40" fill="#7a8b69"/>
    
    <!-- Wombat body -->
    <ellipse cx="550" cy="380" rx="80" ry="65" fill="url(#wombatFur)" filter="url(#shadow)"/>
    
    <!-- Wombat head -->
    <ellipse cx="490" cy="340" rx="50" ry="45" fill="url(#wombatFur)" filter="url(#shadow)"/>
    
    <!-- Wombat ears -->
    <ellipse cx="470" cy="315" rx="15" ry="20" fill="#6b5744"/>
    <ellipse cx="510" cy="315" rx="15" ry="20" fill="#6b5744"/>
    
    <!-- Wombat nose -->
    <ellipse cx="475" cy="350" rx="12" ry="10" fill="#3a2f2f"/>
    
    <!-- Wombat eye -->
    <circle cx="485" cy="335" r="5" fill="#2a2020"/>
    
    <!-- Wombat legs -->
    <ellipse cx="520" cy="430" rx="20" ry="30" fill="#6b5744"/>
    <ellipse cx="580" cy="430" rx="20" ry="30" fill="#6b5744"/>
    
    <!-- Cube-shaped droppings stack -->
    <!-- Bottom cube -->
    <g transform="translate(680, 430)">
      <!-- Front face -->
      <path d="M 0 20 L 35 20 L 35 55 L 0 55 Z" fill="url(#cubeGradient)"/>
      <!-- Top face -->
      <path d="M 0 20 L 10 10 L 45 10 L 35 20 Z" fill="#7a5c4d"/>
      <!-- Side face -->
      <path d="M 35 20 L 45 10 L 45 45 L 35 55 Z" fill="#4a3228"/>
      <!-- Texture -->
      <circle cx="15" cy="35" r="2" fill="#3a2218" opacity="0.5"/>
      <circle cx="25" cy="42" r="1.5" fill="#3a2218" opacity="0.5"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Middle cube -->
    <g transform="translate(670, 390)">
      <path d="M 0 20 L 35 20 L 35 55 L 0 55 Z" fill="url(#cubeGradient)"/>
      <path d="M 0 20 L 10 10 L 45 10 L 35 20 Z" fill="#8b6f57"/>
      <path d="M 35 20 L 45 10 L 45 45 L 35 55 Z" fill="#5c4438"/>
      <circle cx="18" cy="38" r="2" fill="#3a2218" opacity="0.5"/>
      <circle cx="28" cy="45" r="1.5" fill="#3a2218" opacity="0.5"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Top cube -->
    <g transform="translate(685, 350)">
      <path d="M 0 20 L 35 20 L 35 55 L 0 55 Z" fill="url(#cubeGradient)"/>
      <path d="M 0 20 L 10 10 L 45 10 L 35 20 Z" fill="#8b6f57"/>
      <path d="M 35 20 L 45 10 L 45 45 L 35 55 Z" fill="#5c4438"/>
      <circle cx="12" cy="32" r="2" fill="#3a2218" opacity="0.5"/>
      <circle cx="22" cy="40" r="1.5" fill="#3a2218" opacity="0.5"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Additional scattered cube -->
    <g transform="translate(600, 450)">

      <path d="M 0 15 L 8 7 L 36 7 L 28 15 Z" fill="#7a5c4d"/>
      <path d="M 28 15 L 36 7 L 36 35 L 28 43 Z" fill="#4a3228"/>
    </g>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Decorative scientific elements -->
  <circle cx="200" cy="300" r="5" fill="#8b2f47" opacity="0.6"/>
  <circle cx="700" cy="400" r="3" fill="#5c4033" opacity="0.5"/>
  
  <!-- Flow lines connecting panels -->
  <path d="M 300 450 Q 400 500 550 460" stroke="#8b6f47" stroke-width="1.5" fill="none" opacity="0.3" stroke-dasharray="3,3"/>
</svg>

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory and prevent the droppings from rolling away. Scientists discovered in 2021 that this unusual shape is formed by varying elastic properties in the last portion of their intestines, not by a cube-shaped anus as previously theorized.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to varying elasticity in their intestinal walls, and they are indeed the only known animals to produce cubic feces, which they use for territorial marking on elevated surfaces where the shape prevents rolling.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional view of a wombat's lower intestinal tract in scientific diagram style, with the intestinal walls rendered in soft pink and coral tones showing distinct bands of varying tissue elasticity through color gradation—tighter sections in deeper rose, more elastic areas in pale pink. In the foreground, a photorealistic wombat stands on Australian scrubland at golden-hour lighting, with several neat cube-shaped droppings stacked deliberately on a rock or log, their geometric perfection contrasting beautifully with the organic terrain. Small anatomical callouts with clean sans-serif labels should connect the intestinal diagram to the visible results, while the background features muted eucalyptus trees and rust-colored earth, creating an educational yet visually striking composition that balances technical accuracy with natural beauty.

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory. Scientists discovered this happens because of the unique elasticity of their intestinal walls, which have regions of varying stiffness that mold the poop into cubes during the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Wombats do produce cube-shaped feces due to varying elasticity in their intestinal walls that shape the feces in the final portion of the intestine, and they use these cubes to mark territory by stacking them in prominent locations.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional, semi-transparent view of a wombat in profile, rendered in a scientific yet approachable style with warm earth tones and soft educational lighting. The digestive system should be visible through translucent fur, showing the intestinal tract highlighted in peachy-pink with distinct color-coded regions—stiff areas in deep amber and elastic areas in pale yellow—demonstrating how the varying tissue elasticity gradually transforms round fecal matter into geometric cubes in the final section. In the foreground, a photorealistic wombat should be shown stacking several brown, perfectly cubic droppings on a rock or log, with one cube mid-stack to show the behavior in action. Subtle anatomical labels and directional arrows should trace the transformation process, while the background features soft-focused Australian bushland in muted greens and browns to provide natural context without distraction.

  <path d="M 240 368 L 220 370"

  <!-- Nearly cubic -->

  <!-- Stacked cubes on rock (foreground wombat behavior) -->

facts.text: Bananas are naturally radioactive because they contain potassium-40, and eating one gives you a tiny dose of radiation—so much so that truckloads of bananas can trigger radiation sensors at ports designed to detect smuggled nuclear materials.
facts.verification_note: Bananas do contain potassium-40 (a naturally occurring radioactive isotope), which makes them measurably radioactive, and large shipments have indeed triggered radiation portal monitors at ports and border crossings.
facts.image_description: A split-scene illustration in a semi-realistic, editorial style showing a glowing yellow banana in the foreground with subtle green luminescent particles emanating from it, its peel partially peeled back to reveal the fruit inside with faint atomic symbols (⚛️) floating around it. The background depicts a cargo port at dusk with dramatic orange-purple lighting, where a large shipping container truck loaded with banana crates passes through a modern radiation detection portal that's flashing red warning lights and displaying alert signals on digital screens. The composition uses a warm color palette of yellows, oranges, and purples, with the radiation detector's red alerts providing sharp contrast, while dotted lines trace from the bananas to the sensor equipment to show the invisible radiation being detected. Small infographic-style callouts highlight a "K-40" label on one banana and "RADIATION DETECTED" on the portal display, making the scientific concept immediately clear and visually striking.

facts.text: The mantis shrimp can punch with the acceleration of a .22 caliber bullet, creating cavitation bubbles that collapse with a flash of light reaching temperatures nearly as hot as the surface of the sun—around 4,400°C—through a process called sonoluminescence.
facts.verification_note: Mantis shrimp strikes do produce cavitation bubbles that collapse via sonoluminescence at temperatures around 4,400°C (comparable to the sun's surface at ~5,500°C), and their appendages accelerate at rates comparable to a .22 caliber bullet.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a vibrant peacock mantis shrimp in mid-strike against a deep ocean blue background, its raptorial appendage extended forward in a blur of motion with trailing speed lines. At the point of impact, render a explosive burst of translucent cavitation bubbles in iridescent whites and blues, with the central collapsing bubble emanating an intense white-gold flash that illuminates the surrounding water particles. The style should blend photorealistic detail of the shrimp's rainbow-colored carapace (showing its signature greens, oranges, and blues) with scientific illustration clarity, while incorporating a cross-section diagram insert showing the temperature reading of 4,400°C in glowing numbers beside a small comparison graphic of the sun's surface. The lighting should be dramatic and dynamic, with the sonoluminescence flash creating a stark contrast against the darker depths, and bioluminescent-style glows highlighting the physics of this extraordinary natural phenomenon.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>

      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffffff;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#a8d8ff;stop-opacity:0.4" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#4da6ff;stop-opacity:0.2" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="shrimpBody" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#00ff88;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="33%" style="stop-color:#00cc99;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="66%" style="stop-color:#0099cc;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#0066ff;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="shrimpAccent" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ff6600;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#ff9933;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ffcc00;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <filter id="glow">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="4" result="coloredBlur"/>

        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>

      </feMerge>

      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="8" result="coloredBlur"/>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- Background -->
  <rect width="800" height="600" fill="url(#oceanBg)"/>
  
  <!-- Ambient particles -->
  <circle cx="100" cy="80" r="2" fill="#4da6ff" opacity="0.3"/>

  <circle cx="720" cy="450" r="2" fill="#4da6ff" opacity="0.25"/>

  <!-- Mantis Shrimp Body -->
  <g id="shrimp" transform="translate(150, 300)">

    <ellipse cx="-80" cy="0" rx="45" ry="25" fill="url(#shrimpBody)" opacity="0.9"/>

    <!-- Raptorial appendage (extended) -->

      <path d="M 70 0 L 185 -5" stroke="#ff8800" stroke-width="6" fill="none" opacity="0.5"/>

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory. Scientists discovered in 2018 that this happens because wombat intestines have varying elasticity in different regions, with stiffer areas forming the edges and softer areas forming the faces of the cubes as the digestive process compresses the waste.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2018 by Patricia Yang and colleagues demonstrated that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to varying elasticity in their intestinal walls, with stiffer regions forming cube edges and more elastic regions forming faces, and wombats do stack these cubes to mark territory.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional scientific diagram in a modern, clean educational style with a wombat in profile on the left side, its digestive system visible through a translucent body rendered in soft earth tones of browns and tans. The intestinal tract should be prominently featured with color-coded regions—vibrant blues indicating stiffer, less elastic areas at the edges and warm oranges/reds showing softer, more elastic regions on the faces—with small arrows demonstrating how compression forces shape the waste into cubes. In the background, a subtle Australian landscape should fade into view, while in the foreground, a neat stack of geometric, cube-shaped droppings sits on ochre-colored earth, their edges catching golden-hour lighting to emphasize their remarkable angular geometry. Small anatomical labels and dotted lines should connect the intestinal regions to corresponding cube faces, creating a bridge between the biological mechanism and its extraordinary result.

facts.text: When you get a sunburn, you're not actually feeling the sun's heat damaging your skin—you're feeling your own cells committing suicide. Your skin cells detect UV damage to their DNA and trigger apoptosis (programmed cell death) to prevent becoming cancerous, and the redness and pain you experience is the inflammation from millions of your cells simultaneously self-destructing.
facts.verification_note: Sunburn pain and redness are indeed primarily caused by inflammatory responses triggered by UV-induced DNA damage and subsequent apoptosis of keratinocytes, rather than direct thermal damage from the sun's heat.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-section of human skin in a semi-translucent, scientific illustration style with dramatic lighting. In the upper layers, individual skin cells glow with an ominous amber-orange light as they undergo apoptosis, their DNA helixes visible and fragmenting like shattered glass, while UV rays (represented as sharp, violet-blue beams) pierce down from above. The surrounding tissue shows waves of red inflammation spreading outward like ripples, with white blood cells rendered as ghostly, luminescent forms moving through the dermal layers. The composition should contrast the cool, destructive UV light from above with the warm, fiery colors of the inflammatory response below, creating a battlefield-like scene where millions of cells sacrifice themselves in a coordinated defense, their membranes rupturing in synchronized bursts of coral and crimson.

  <!-- Apoptotic cells in upper layer with DNA fragments -->

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory. Scientists discovered in 2021 that this unusual shape is formed by varying elasticity in the wombat's intestinal walls, with softer tissue creating the flat sides and stiffer regions forming the corners—preventing the droppings from rolling away on uneven terrain.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2018 (not 2021) by Patricia Yang and colleagues confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to varying elasticity in their intestinal walls, and they do use these distinctive droppings to mark territory, with the shape preventing them from rolling away.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional view of a wombat's digestive system in scientific illustration style, with a cutaway showing the intestinal walls in warm pinks and reds, clearly labeled with color-coded regions indicating varying tissue elasticity—softer areas in lighter rose tones and stiffer regions in deeper burgundy. In the foreground, a photorealistic wombat should be positioned on rocky, uneven Australian terrain at golden hour, actively stacking several glossy, dark brown cube-shaped droppings that catch the warm sunlight, emphasizing their geometric precision and flat surfaces. Small inset diagrams with clean lines and arrows should show the physics of how round droppings would roll away versus how the cubes remain stable, while native eucalyptus trees and rust-colored rocks frame the composition, grounding the surreal geometric feces in their natural habitat.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">

  <defs>

      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#FFA07A;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#FFD4A3;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#E8B687;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="groundGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#B87860;stop-opacity:1" />

    </linearGradient>
    
    <!-- Intestinal wall gradients -->
    <linearGradient id="softTissue" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#FFB6C1;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#FFC0CB;stop-opacity:0.9" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="stiffTissue" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#8B1A1A;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#A52A2A;stop-opacity:0.9" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="mediumTissue" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#CD5C5C;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#DC143C;stop-opacity:0.9" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <!-- Cube droppings gradient -->
    <linearGradient id="cubeGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#5D4037;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#3E2723;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#4E342E;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <!-- Shine effect -->
    <radialGradient id="shine" cx="30%" cy="30%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#FFFFFF;stop-opacity:0.3" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#FFFFFF;stop-opacity:0" />
    </radialGradient>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- Sky background -->
  <rect width="800" height="600" fill="url(#skyGradient)"/>
  
  <!-- Ground/terrain -->
  <path d="M 0 400 Q 200 380 400 390 T 800 400 L 800 600 L 0 600 Z" fill="url(#groundGradient)"/>
  
  <!-- Eucalyptus trees in background -->
  <ellipse cx="100" cy="250" rx="30" ry="80" fill="#5D7C5A" opacity="0.6"/>

  <rect x="95" y="300" width="15" height="100" fill="#6D4C41" opacity="0.6"/>
  
  <ellipse cx="700" cy="270" rx="35" ry="90" fill="#5D7C5A" opacity="0.6"/>
  <ellipse cx="680" cy="260" rx="30" ry="75" fill="#6B8E68" opacity="0.6"/>
  <rect x="690" y="320" width="18" height="80" fill="#6D4C41" opacity="0.6"/>

  <ellipse cx="320" cy="415" rx="30" ry="18" fill="#B8956A" opacity="0.8"/>

    <!-- Outer intestinal wall -->
    <ellipse cx="100" cy="80" rx="90" ry="70" fill="#F4A7A7" opacity="0.3"/>
    
    <!-- Inner cross-section showing tissue layers -->
    <path d="M 40 80 Q 40 40 100 30 Q 160 40 160 80 Q 160 120 100 130 Q 40 120 40 80 Z" 
          fill="url(#softTissue)" stroke="#CD5C5C" stroke-width="2"/>
    
    <!-- Stiffer tissue regions (corners) -->

    <circle cx="140" cy="60" r="12" fill="url(#stiffTissue)"/>
    <circle cx="140" cy="100" r="12" fill="url(#stiffTissue)"/>
    <circle cx="60" cy="100" r="12" fill="url(#stiffTissue)"/>
    
    <!-- Medium elasticity regions -->
    <ellipse cx="100" cy="50" rx="25" ry="10" fill="url(#mediumTissue)"/>
    <ellipse cx="100" cy="110" rx="25" ry="10" fill="url(#mediumTissue)"/>
    <ellipse cx="50" cy="80" rx="10" ry="25" fill="url(#mediumTissue)"/>
    <ellipse cx="150" cy="80" rx="10" ry="25" fill="url(#mediumTissue)"/>
    
    <!-- Central lumen -->
    <rect x="75" y="65" width="50" height="30" fill="#8B4513" opacity="0.6" rx="5"/>
    
    <!-- Arrows indicating pressure points -->
    <path d="M 30 80 L 40 80" stroke="#8B1A1A" stroke-width="2" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
    <path d="M 170 80 L 160 80" stroke="#8B1A1A" stroke-width="2" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
  </g>
  
  <marker id="arrowhead" markerWidth="10" markerHeight="7" refX="9" refY="3.5" orient="auto">
    <polygon points="0 0, 10 3.5, 0 7" fill="#8B1A1A"/>

  <!-- Wombat body (photorealistic style) -->
  <g transform="translate(250, 320)">

    <ellipse cx="45" cy="40" rx="8" ry="14" fill="#8D7B6F"/>
    
    <!-- Nose -->
    <ellipse cx="20" cy="70" rx="8" ry="6" fill="#4A3F37"/>
    
    <!-- Eye -->
    <circle cx="35" cy="55" r="4" fill="#2C1810"/>
    
    <!-- Legs -->
    <ellipse cx="50" cy="125" rx="20" ry="25" fill="#6B5D54"/>
    <ellipse cx="90" cy="125" rx="20" ry="25" fill="#6B5D54"/>
    <ellipse cx="120" cy="125" rx="18" ry="23" fill="#6B5D54"/>
    <ellipse cx="155" cy="125" rx="18" ry="23" fill="#6B5D54"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Cube-shaped droppings stack -->
  <g transform="translate(450, 380)">
    <!-- Bottom cube -->
    <g>
      <path d="M 0 40 L 30 25 L 60 40 L 30 55 Z" fill="url(#cubeGradient)"/>
      <path d="M 0 40 L 0 10 L 30 -5 L 30 25 Z" fill="#3E2723"/>
      <path d="M 30 25 L 30 -5 L 60 10 L 60 40 Z" fill="#4E342E"/>
      <ellipse cx="15" cy="20" rx="8" ry="6" fill="url(#shine)"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Middle cube -->
    <g transform="translate(0, -35)">
      <path d="M 0 40 L 30 25 L 60 40 L 30 55 Z" fill="url(#cubeGradient)"/>
      <path d="M 0 40 L 0 10 L 30 -5 L 30 25 Z" fill="#3E2723"/>
      <path d="M 30 25 L 30 -5 L 60 10 L 60 40 Z" fill="#4E342E"/>
      <ellipse cx="15" cy="20" rx="8" ry="6" fill="url(#shine)"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Top cube -->
    <g transform="translate(0, -70)">
      <path d="M 0 40 L 30 25 L 60 40 L 30 55 Z" fill="url(#cubeGradient)"/>
      <path d="M 0 40 L 0 10 L 30 -5 L 30 25 Z" fill="#3E2723"/>
      <path d="M 30 25 L 30 -5 L 60 10 L 60 40 Z" fill="#4E342E"/>
      <ellipse cx="15" cy="20" rx="8" ry="6" fill="url(#shine)"/>
    </g>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Additional scattered cubes -->
  <g transform="translate(380, 420)">
    <path d="M 0 20 L 15 12 L 30 20 L 15 28 Z" fill="url(#cubeGradient)"/>
    <path d="M 0 20 L 0 5 L 15 -3 L 15 12 Z" fill="#3E2723"/>
    <path d="M 15 12 L 15 -3 L 30 5 L 30 20 Z" fill="#4E342E"/>
  </g>
  
  <g transform="translate(550, 410)">

  </g>
  
  <!-- Physics diagram inset (upper right) -->

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark territory and prevent them from rolling away. Their intestines have varying elasticity in different sections, with stiffer regions molding the poop into distinctive cubes over the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Scientific research has confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to varying elasticity in their intestinal walls during the final portion of digestion, and they use these cubes as territorial markers that resist rolling on uneven terrain.
facts.image_description: The illustration should feature a cross-sectional, semi-transparent view of a wombat in profile, rendered in a scientific yet approachable style with warm earth tones and soft educational lighting. The digestive tract should be clearly visible in translucent pink and coral hues, with the final 8% of the intestines highlighted in deeper rose tones and showing distinct bands of varying elasticity—stiffer sections appearing in darker burgundy stripes that visibly compress the fecal matter into angular, cube-like shapes. In the foreground, a realistic wombat should be shown stacking several dark brown, perfectly geometric cube-shaped droppings on a rock or log, with a few cubes already arranged in a small territorial pile, their sharp edges and flat surfaces catching dappled sunlight filtering through eucalyptus trees. Anatomical labels and subtle directional arrows should indicate the transformation process, while the background features the Australian bush habitat in muted greens and golden browns to provide context without distraction.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <linearGradient id="skyGrad" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#d4b896;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#a89968;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="wombatFur" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#8b7355;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#6b5644;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#5a4a3a;stop-opacity:0.9" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="intestineGrad" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffb3ba;stop-opacity:0.7" />
      <stop offset="70%" style="stop-color:#ff9aa2;stop-opacity:0.7" />
      <stop offset="85%" style="stop-color:#d8737f;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#a84a57;stop-opacity:0.9" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="cubeShade" cx="40%" cy="40%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#6b4423;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#3d2817;stop-opacity:1" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <filter id="glow">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="2" result="coloredBlur"/>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
    
    <pattern id="eucalyptus" patternUnits="userSpaceOnUse" width="100" height="100">

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark territory and prevent them from rolling away. Scientists discovered in 2021 that this unique shape is formed by varying elasticity in the final 8% of their intestines, where softer tissue regions create flat sides while stiffer regions form edges.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces through differential elasticity in the last 8% of their intestines, and they do use these cubes to mark territory, with the shape preventing rolling on slopes.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional scientific diagram in a warm, earthy color palette, showing a wombat in profile on the left side with a cutaway view revealing the final portion of its intestinal tract in peachy-pink tones, with clearly labeled regions of varying elasticity shown in contrasting shades of rose and coral. The intestinal walls should display visible striations where softer (darker pink) and stiffer (lighter, almost cream-colored) tissue regions alternate, with small arrows indicating how these zones sculpt the feces into cubic form. In the foreground, several glossy, perfectly geometric cube-shaped droppings should be artfully stacked on Australian red earth, casting subtle shadows in golden-hour lighting, while a few scattered cubes show the territorial marking pattern. The style should blend photorealistic texture for the wombat's coarse fur and the soil with clean, educational diagram aesthetics for the anatomical elements, using a soft depth-of-field effect to emphasize both the scientific mechanism and its remarkable real-world result.

facts.text: Tardigrades, microscopic animals also known as water bears, can survive being frozen to almost absolute zero (-272°C), heated to 150°C, exposed to the vacuum of space, and blasted with radiation doses 1,000 times higher than what would kill a human. When conditions become too harsh, they expel nearly all water from their bodies and enter a death-like state called cryptobiosis, where they can remain for decades before being revived with just a drop of water.
facts.verification_note: All stated claims about tardigrade survival capabilities and cryptobiosis are well-documented in peer-reviewed scientific literature, including their survival at near absolute zero temperatures, extreme heat tolerance, vacuum exposure during space experiments, high radiation resistance (up to 5,000-6,000 Gy compared to human lethal dose of ~5-10 Gy), and their ability to survive decades in a desiccated cryptobiotic state before rehydration.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a magnified tardigrade as the central figure, rendered in a semi-translucent, bioluminescent style with soft blues and ethereal whites against a dark cosmic background. The water bear should be shown in its active state on one side—plump and glowing—while the other side transitions into its dehydrated, cryptobiotic form with a crystalline, amber-tinted appearance. Surrounding the tardigrade, create a circular composition featuring four distinct environmental zones: a frozen ice crystal section with deep blues, a fiery orange-red heated zone, a star-speckled space vacuum with swirling nebulas, and a radiation zone depicted with sharp, neon-green geometric rays. The lighting should emphasize the tardigrade's eight stubby legs and characteristic bear-like face, with a single droplet of water hovering nearby, catching light like a prism to symbolize its revival capability.

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory. Scientists discovered this happens because wombat intestines have varying elasticity in different regions, with sections of stiff and flexible tissue that mold the poop into cubic form during the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to varying intestinal elasticity that creates the cubic shape in the final 8% of the intestine, and they do use these cubes to mark territory, making them unique among animals.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional, semi-transparent view of a wombat in profile, rendered in a scientific yet approachable style with warm earth tones and soft educational lighting. The digestive tract should be highlighted in translucent amber and pink hues, with the final section of the intestines shown in detailed cutaway, revealing alternating bands of stiff tissue (depicted in deeper burgundy) and flexible tissue (shown in peachy-pink) that create visible geometric pressure points shaping the fecal matter into distinctive cubes. In the foreground, a content wombat should be shown depositing neat stacks of cubic droppings on a rock or log, with 2-3 perfect brown cubes already arranged like nature's building blocks, while the background features the dusky Australian bush in muted greens and purples. Small anatomical labels with delicate line work should point to key intestinal regions, and a small scale indicator showing "final 8%" should appear near the cube-forming section, all rendered in a style that balances National Geographic precision with the whimsical charm of the subject matter.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">

      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#6B5345;stop-opacity:0.9" />

    <linearGradient id="digestiveTract" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">

      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#FF8C69;stop-opacity:0.6" />
    </linearGradient>
    <linearGradient id="intestineStiff" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#8B3A62;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#A0466F;stop-opacity:0.8" />
    </linearGradient>
    <linearGradient id="intestineFlexible" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#FFB6A3;stop-opacity:0.7" />

    <radialGradient id="cubeGradient" cx="40%" cy="40%">

  <!-- Wombat legs -->

  <path d="M 470 465 Q 480 475 490 480 Q 500 485 510 490"

    <rect x="0" y="85" width="140" height="25" rx="5" fill="url(#intestineFlexible)" stroke="#FF9580" stroke-width="1"/>

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory. Scientists discovered in 2021 that this unusual shape is created by varying elasticity in the final section of their intestines, with softer tissue regions forming the corners and stiffer regions forming the flat sides.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to differential elasticity in their intestinal walls, and they do use these cubes to mark territory, making wombats unique among animals in this regard.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional view of a wombat's lower intestine in scientific diagram style, rendered in warm earth tones and soft pinks for the tissue. The intestinal walls should be clearly labeled with color-coded regions showing alternating bands of darker pink (stiffer tissue) and lighter, more translucent pink (softer, more elastic tissue), with arrows indicating how these regions sculpt the passing waste into geometric corners and flat planes. In the foreground, a photorealistic wombat should be shown in its natural Australian habitat at golden hour, with several perfectly stacked cube-shaped droppings arranged on a rock or log behind it, their geometric precision contrasting beautifully with the organic bush setting. The lighting should be warm and natural, with a subtle spotlight effect on the anatomical diagram to emphasize the scientific discovery, while maintaining an engaging balance between educational clarity and visual appeal.

  <!-- Cube 3 -->

    <polygon points="0,20 20,10 40,20 40,40 20,50 0,40" fill="url(#cubeTop)"/>
    <polygon points="0,20 0,40 20,50 20,30" fill="url(#cubeSide)"/>
    <polygon points="40,20 40,40 20,50 20,30" fill="#3B2817"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Scientific diagram background -->
  <circle cx="550" cy="180" r="160" fill="url(#spotlight)"/>
  <rect x="420" y="40" width="260" height="280" fill="#FFF8DC" opacity="0.9" rx="10"/>
  <rect x="425" y="45" width="250" height="270" fill="none" stroke="#8B6F47" stroke-width="2" rx="8"/>
  
  <!-- Intestine cross-section -->
  <g transform="translate(550, 180)">
    <!-- Outer intestine wall -->
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="0" rx="100" ry="100" fill="#E6A8B8" stroke="#C75B7A" stroke-width="2"/>
    
    <!-- Inner passage -->
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="0" rx="40" ry="40" fill="#F5DEB3" stroke="#D2B48C" stroke-width="1"/>
    
    <!-- Tissue regions - alternating bands -->
    <!-- Stiff region 1 (top) -->
    <path d="M -70,-70 A 100,100 0 0,1 70,-70 L 28,-28 A 40,40 0 0,0 -28,-28 Z" fill="url(#stiffTissue)" opacity="0.9"/>
    
    <!-- Soft region 1 (top-right corner) -->
    <path d="M 70,-70 A 100,100 0 0,1 100,0 L 40,0 A 40,40 0 0,0 28,-28 Z" fill="url(#softTissue)" opacity="0.8"/>
    
    <!-- Stiff region 2 (right) -->
    <path d="M 100,0 A 100,100 0 0,1 70,70 L 28,28 A 40,40 0 0,0 40,0 Z" fill="url(#stiffTissue)" opacity="0.9"/>
    
    <!-- Soft region 2 (bottom-right corner) -->
    <path d="M 70,70 A 100,100 0 0,1 0,100 L 0,40 A 40,40 0 0,0 28,28 Z" fill="url(#softTissue)" opacity="0.8"/>
    
    <!-- Stiff region 3 (bottom) -->
    <path d="M 0,100 A 100,100 0 0,1 -70,70 L -28,28 A 40,40 0 0,0 0,40 Z" fill="url(#stiffTissue)" opacity="0.9"/>
    
    <!-- Soft region 3 (bottom-left corner) -->
    <path d="M -70,70 A 100,100 0 0,1 -100,0 L -40,0 A 40,40 0 0,0 -28,28 Z" fill="url(#softTissue)" opacity="0.8"/>
    
    <!-- Stiff region 4 (left) -->
    <path d="M -100,0 A 100,100 0 0,1 -70,-70 L -28,-28 A 40,40 0 0,0 -40,0 Z" fill="url(#stiffTissue)" opacity="0.9"/>
    
    <!-- Soft region 4 (top-left corner) -->
    <path d="M -70,-70 A 100,100 0 0,1 0,-100 L 0,-40 A 40,40 0 0,0 -28,-28 Z" fill="url(#softTissue)" opacity="0.8"/>
    
    <!-- Forming cube shape in center -->
    <rect x="-20" y="-20" width="40" height="40" fill="#D2B48C" stroke="#8B6F47" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.7"/>
    
    <!-- Directional arrows showing compression -->
    <g stroke="#C75B7A" stroke-width="2" fill="none" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)">
      <defs>
        <marker id="arrowhead" markerWidth="10" markerHeight="10" refX="9" refY="3" orient="auto">
          <polygon points="0 0, 10 3, 0 6" fill="#C75B7A"/>
        </marker>
      </defs>
      <path d="M -80,0 L -45,0" />
      <path d="M 80,0 L 45,0" />
      <path d="M 0,-80 L 0,-45" />
      <path d="M 0,80 L 0,45" />
    </g>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Decorative elements - Australian bush -->
  <ellipse cx="120" cy="520" rx="60" ry="30" fill="#5C8A5C" opacity="0.6"/>
  <ellipse cx="700" cy="530" rx="70" ry="35" fill="#6B9B6B" opacity="0.5"/>
  
  <!-- Small grass tufts -->
  <path d="M 50,500 Q 55,480 60,500" stroke="#7A9A5A" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/>
  <path d="M 60,500 Q 65,485 70,500" stroke="#7A9A5A" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/>
  <path d="M 750,510 Q 755,495 760,510" stroke="#8AAA6A" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/>
  <path d="M 740,515 Q 745,500 750,515" stroke="#8AAA6A" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/>
</svg>

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory and prevent the droppings from rolling away. Scientists discovered this happens because wombat intestines have varying elasticity in different regions, with stiff and flexible sections that mold the poop into cubes during the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces through varying intestinal elasticity in the final portion of their intestines, and they do use these distinctive droppings to mark territory on elevated surfaces where the cubic shape prevents rolling.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional, semi-transparent view of a wombat in profile, rendered in a scientific yet approachable style with soft, naturalistic colors—earthy browns for the wombat's fur and pink-to-coral tones for the intestinal tract. The digestive system should be prominently highlighted and partially visible through the wombat's body, with color-coded regions showing stiff sections (deeper red) and flexible sections (lighter pink) of the intestines, with small arrows or labels indicating how these varying elasticities shape the feces into distinctive cubes during the final portion. In the foreground, a small stack of perfectly geometric, cube-shaped droppings should sit on Australian bushland terrain, catching warm golden-hour lighting that emphasizes their unusual angular edges, while the background shows a subtle outback landscape with native grasses and rocks to provide environmental context.

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory and prevent them from rolling away. Scientists discovered this happens because of the unique elasticity of the wombat's intestinal walls, which have regions of varying stiffness that literally mold the poop into cubes over the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces through varying elasticity in their intestinal walls during the final 8% of the intestine, and they do stack these cubes as territorial markers that resist rolling.
facts.image_description: The illustration should be a split-panel scientific diagram in a clean, modern educational style with a soft natural color palette of earthy browns, pinks, and greens. The left panel shows a cross-sectional cutaway of a wombat's digestive system in semi-transparent anatomical detail, with the intestinal walls color-coded in gradient shades from soft pink to deeper rose to indicate varying stiffness levels, and small cube-shaped feces visible in the final section with directional arrows showing the molding process. The right panel depicts a photorealistic wombat in dappled forest lighting, positioned beside a small stack of its distinctive cubic droppings arranged on a rock or log, with a few scattered cubes nearby to emphasize their geometric perfection and non-rolling properties. Subtle informational callouts with thin lines point to key features, while the overall composition balances scientific accuracy with visual appeal through warm, inviting lighting that makes the subject matter approachable rather than clinical.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">

      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffb3ba;stop-opacity:0.7" />

      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#d87c85;stop-opacity:0.9" />

      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#6b5d52;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#8b7a6b;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#5a4d42;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="cubeGradient" cx="40%" cy="40%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#8b6f47;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#5d4a2f;stop-opacity:1" />

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory. Their intestines have varying elasticity in different sections, with stiffer regions molding the poop into cubes during the final 8% of the digestive process, preventing them from rolling away on uneven terrain.
facts.verification_note: Scientific research has confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces through varying intestinal elasticity in the final portion of digestion, and they do use these distinctive droppings to mark territory, with the cubic shape preventing rolling on slopes.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional scientific diagram in warm earth tones, showing a wombat's digestive system in semi-transparent anatomical detail on the left side, with the intestinal walls color-coded in gradients from pink to deep amber to indicate varying elasticity levels. The right side shows a sturdy wombat in its natural Australian bushland habitat at golden-hour lighting, actively stacking distinctive cube-shaped droppings on a mossy rock outcrop, with several perfectly geometric brown cubes already arranged like tiny building blocks that remain stable on the slanted surface. Small annotative arrows and percentage markers (highlighting the final 8% section) connect the intestinal diagram to the cube formation process, while inset magnified views show the intestinal wall structure creating the geometric edges, all rendered in a detailed scientific illustration style that balances educational clarity with engaging, slightly whimsical realism.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <linearGradient id="skyGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#f4d4a8;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#e8b875;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="groundGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#8b7355;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#5d4a3a;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="intestineGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffb3ba;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="40%" style="stop-color:#f4a582;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="70%" style="stop-color:#e8885f;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="92%" style="stop-color:#d67348;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#b85c3a;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="wombatFur" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#6b5444;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#4a3a2a;stop-opacity:1" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="rockGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#8a8a7a;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#5a5a4a;stop-opacity:1" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="cubeGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#8b6f47;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#5d4a2f;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <filter id="shadow">
      <feGaussianBlur in="SourceAlpha" stdDeviation="3"/>
      <feOffset dx="2" dy="2" result="offsetblur"/>
      <feComponentTransfer>
        <feFuncA type="linear" slope="0.3"/>
      </feComponentTransfer>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- Background -->
  <rect width="800" height="600" fill="url(#skyGradient)"/>
  
  <!-- Ground on right side -->
  <path d="M 400 400 Q 450 380 500 400 L 800 400 L 800 600 L 400 600 Z" fill="url(#groundGradient)"/>
  
  <!-- Left side - Anatomical diagram background -->
  <rect x="0" y="0" width="400" height="600" fill="#f5e6d3" opacity="0.9"/>
  
  <!-- Wombat silhouette outline (left side) -->
  <ellipse cx="150" cy="200" rx="80" ry="60" fill="#e8d5c0" opacity="0.3"/>
  
  <!-- Digestive system diagram -->
  <g id="digestiveSystem" transform="translate(80, 100)">
    <!-- Stomach -->
    <ellipse cx="70" cy="50" rx="35" ry="30" fill="#ffb3ba" opacity="0.6"/>
    
    <!-- Intestinal tract - curved path showing gradient -->
    <path d="M 70 80 Q 120 100 130 150 Q 135 200 120 250 Q 100 300 80 350 Q 60 380 50 420" 
          stroke="url(#intestineGradient)" stroke-width="30" fill="none" opacity="0.85" stroke-linecap="round"/>
    
    <!-- Highlight the final 8% section -->
    <path d="M 80 350 Q 60 380 50 420" 
          stroke="#b85c3a" stroke-width="32" fill="none" opacity="0.95" stroke-linecap="round"/>
    
    <!-- Cross-section details showing wall structure -->
    <g transform="translate(30, 380)">
      <rect x="0" y="0" width="40" height="50" fill="#d67348" opacity="0.7" rx="3"/>
      <rect x="5" y="5" width="30" height="40" fill="#e8885f" opacity="0.6" rx="2"/>
      <!-- Muscle fibers -->
      <line x1="10" y1="10" x2="35" y2="10" stroke="#b85c3a" stroke-width="2"/>
      <line x1="10" y1="20" x2="35" y2="20" stroke="#b85c3a" stroke-width="2"/>
      <line x1="10" y1="30" x2="35" y2="30" stroke="#b85c3a" stroke-width="2"/>
      <line x1="10" y1="40" x2="35" y2="40" stroke="#b85c3a" stroke-width="2"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Percentage markers -->
    <circle cx="120" cy="150" r="8" fill="#f4a582" stroke="#fff" stroke-width="2"/>
    <circle cx="100" cy="250" r="8" fill="#e8885f" stroke="#fff" stroke-width="2"/>
    <circle cx="50" cy="400" r="10" fill="#b85c3a" stroke="#fff" stroke-width="2"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Arrows connecting diagram to wombat -->
  <g id="arrows">
    <path d="M 200 500 Q 300 480 380 450" stroke="#d67348" stroke-width="3" fill="none" 
          marker-end="url(#arrowhead)" stroke-dasharray="5,5"/>
    <defs>
      <marker id="arrowhead" markerWidth="10" markerHeight="10" refX="9" refY="3" orient="auto">
        <polygon points="0 0, 10 3, 0 6" fill="#d67348"/>
      </marker>
    </defs>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Right side - Natural habitat scene -->
  <!-- Rock outcrop -->
  <g id="rockOutcrop">
    <ellipse cx="600" cy="450" rx="120" ry="80" fill="url(#rockGradient)" filter="url(#shadow)"/>
    <ellipse cx="580" cy="440" rx="60" ry="40" fill="#6a6a5a" opacity="0.6"/>
    <!-- Moss patches -->
    <ellipse cx="560" cy="480" rx="20" ry="10" fill="#7a9b6f" opacity="0.7"/>
    <ellipse cx="620" cy="470" rx="25" ry="12" fill="#6b8c5f" opacity="0.7"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Wombat -->
  <g id="wombat" transform="translate(480, 380)">
    <!-- Body -->
    <ellipse cx="70" cy="50" rx="65" ry="45" fill="url(#wombatFur)" filter="url(#shadow)"/>
    <!-- Head -->
    <ellipse cx="20" cy="35" rx="35" ry="30" fill="url(#wombatFur)"/>
    <!-- Ears -->
    <ellipse cx="10" cy="18" rx="12" ry="15" fill="#5a4a3a"/>
    <ellipse cx="30" cy="18" rx="12" ry="15" fill="#5a4a3a"/>
    <!-- Nose -->
    <ellipse cx="8" cy="42" rx="8" ry="6" fill="#3a2a1a"/>
    <!-- Eye -->
    <circle cx="18" cy="32" r="3" fill="#2a2a2a"/>
    <!-- Legs -->
    <ellipse cx="45" cy="80" rx="15" ry="20" fill="#5a4a3a"/>
    <ellipse cx="75" cy="80" rx="15" ry="20" fill="#5a4a3a"/>
    <!-- Front paw reaching -->
    <ellipse cx="25" cy="65" rx="12" ry="18" fill="#5a4a3a"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Cube-shaped droppings stacked on rock -->
  <g id="cubes">
    <!-- Bottom cubes -->
    <g transform="translate(580, 410)">
      <polygon points="0,20 15,10 30,20 15,30" fill="#8b6f47"/>
      <polygon points="0,20 0,0 15,10 15,30" fill="#6b5437"/>
      <polygon points="15,10 30,0 30,20 15,30" fill="#5d4a2f"/>
    </g>
    
    <g transform="translate(615, 415)">
      <polygon points="0,20 15,10 30,20 15,30" fill="#8b6f47"/>
      <polygon points="0,20 0,0 15,10 15,30" fill="#6b5437"/>
      <polygon points="15,10 30,0 30,20 15,30" fill="#5d4a2f"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Middle cube -->
    <g transform="translate(598, 390)">
      <polygon points="0,20 15,10 30,20 15,30" fill="#8b6f47"/>
      <polygon points="0,20 0,0 15,10 15,30" fill="#6b5437"/>
      <polygon points="15,10 30,0 30,20 15,30" fill="#5d4a2f"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Top cube -->
    <g transform="translate(598, 370)">
      <polygon points="0,20 15,10 30,20 15,30" fill="#9b7f57"/>
      <polygon points="0,20 0,0 15,10 15,30" fill="#7b6447"/>
      <polygon points="15,10 30,0 30,20 15,30" fill="#6d5a3f"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Cube being placed -->
    <g transform="translate(530, 365)">
      <polygon points="0,20 15,10 30,20 15,30" fill="#9b7f57" opacity="0.9"/>
      <polygon points="0,20 0,0 15,10 15,30" fill="#7b6447" opacity="0.9"/>
      <polygon points="15,10 30,0 30,20 15,30" fill="#6d5a3f" opacity="0.9"/>
    </g>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Vegetation -->
  <g id="vegetation">
    <!-- Grass tufts -->
    <path d="M 420 450 Q 425 430 430 450" stroke="#7a9b6f" stroke-width="3" fill="none"/>
    <path d="M 428 450 Q 433 425 438 450" stroke="#6b8c5f" stroke-width="3" fill="none"/>
    <path d="M 435 450 Q 440 435 445 450" stroke="#7a9b6f" stroke-width="3" fill="none"/>
    
    <path d="M 720 460 Q 725 440 730 460" stroke="#7a9b6f" stroke-width="3" fill="none"/>
    <path d="M 728 460 Q 733 435 738 460" stroke="#6b8c5f" stroke-width="3" fill="none"/>
    
    <!-- Small bushes -->
    <ellipse cx="750" cy="420" rx="30" ry="25" fill="#6b8c5f" opacity="0.7"/>
    <ellipse cx="770" cy="425" rx="25" ry="20" fill="#7a9b6f" opacity="0.7"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Magnified inset showing intestinal structure -->
  <g id="magnifiedInset" transform="translate(250, 450)">
    <rect x="0" y="0" width="120" height="100" fill="#fff" stroke="#d67348" stroke-width="3" rx="5" opacity="0.95"/>
    <!-- Intestinal wall layers -->
    <rect x="10" y="20" width="100" height="15" fill="#ffb3ba" opacity="0.7" rx="2"/>
    <rect x="10" y="40" width="100" height="15" fill="#e8885f" opacity="0.7" rx="2"/>
    <rect x="10" y="60" width="100" height="15" fill="#b85c3a" opacity="0.8" rx="2"/>
    
    <!-- Compression arrows -->
    <path d="M 20 10 L 20 20" stroke="#d67348" stroke-width="2" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
    <path d="M 50 10 L 50 20" stroke="#d67348" stroke-width="2" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
    <path d="M 80 10 L 80 20" stroke="#d67348" stroke-width="2" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
    
    <!-- Resulting cube shape -->
    <g transform="translate(30, 80)">
      <polygon points="0,8 6,4 12,8 6,12" fill="#8b6f47" stroke="#5d4a2f" stroke-width="1"/>
    </g>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Connection line from inset to main diagram -->
  <path d="M 250 500 L 150 450" stroke="#d67348" stroke-width="2" stroke-dasharray="3,3" opacity="0.6"/>
</svg>

facts.text: The mantis shrimp can punch with the acceleration of a .22 caliber bullet, creating cavitation bubbles that collapse with a flash of light reaching temperatures nearly as hot as the surface of the sun (around 4,400°C). This underwater shockwave is so powerful it can kill prey even if the punch misses.
facts.verification_note: Scientific studies confirm mantis shrimp strikes reach accelerations comparable to .22 bullets (over 10,000 g), produce cavitation bubbles that emit light (sonoluminescence) at approximately 4,700°C, and generate shockwaves capable of stunning or killing prey independently of physical contact.
facts.image_description: The illustration should capture a split-second moment in crystalline underwater clarity: a vibrant peacock mantis shrimp (with electric blues, greens, and orange segments) mid-strike, its raptorial appendage extended in a blur of motion toward a small crab. Surrounding the impact point, render translucent cavitation bubbles in various stages of collapse, with the central ones exploding in brilliant white-hot flashes of 4,400°C light that create dramatic lens flares and illuminate the surrounding water in golden-orange halos. The style should blend scientific illustration precision with dynamic action photography, showing visible shockwave ripples radiating outward in concentric rings through the blue-green water, while the stunned prey begins to drift backward from the force—all set against a coral reef background slightly blurred to emphasize the explosive focal point. Include a subtle technical overlay showing the punch trajectory and temperature reading to reinforce the scientific nature of this remarkable phenomenon.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">

    <radialGradient id="heatGlow" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffffff;stop-opacity:0.9"/>
      <stop offset="30%" style="stop-color:#ffcc00;stop-opacity:0.6"/>
      <stop offset="70%" style="stop-color:#ff8800;stop-opacity:0.3"/>
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ff4400;stop-opacity:0"/>

      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#00ffcc;stop-opacity:1"/>
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#0088ff;stop-opacity:1"/>
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#0044cc;stop-opacity:1"/>
    </linearGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="cavitationBubble" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">

    <filter id="glow">

    <filter id="strongGlow">

  <!-- Shockwave rings -->

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory and prevent the droppings from rolling away. Scientists discovered this happens because the final 8% of their intestine has varying elasticity in its walls, with two grooved regions that shape the waste into cubes as it dries out.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2018-2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to varying elasticity in the final portion of their intestines, with the distinctive shape formed by alternating stiff and flexible regions of the intestinal wall, and they do use these cubes to mark territory on elevated surfaces where the shape prevents rolling.
facts.image_description: The illustration should feature a cross-sectional anatomical view of a wombat's lower intestine in the style of a vintage scientific diagram, with warm sepia tones and precise line work against a cream-colored parchment background. The intestinal walls should be rendered in soft pinks and reds, with two distinct darker grooved regions clearly visible that compress the waste material, shown in a gradient from brown mush to perfectly formed brown cubes. In the foreground, a photorealistic wombat should be positioned beside a small stack of its distinctive cubic droppings on rocky terrain, with the animal rendered in rich browns and grays under natural sunlight that casts subtle shadows emphasizing the geometric edges of the feces. Delicate dotted lines and elegant labels in a classic serif font should connect the anatomical detail to the real-world result, while small percentage markers (92% and 8%) highlight the critical final section of the intestine where the cube-formation occurs.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <!-- Parchment background -->
  <defs>
    <radialGradient id="parchment" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="70%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#f5e6d3;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#e8d4b8;stop-opacity:1" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="intestineWall" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#d4a5a5;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#e8b4b4;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#d4a5a5;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="intestineInner" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#f0c8c8;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#fad8d8;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#f0c8c8;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="wasteGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#8b6f47;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="30%" style="stop-color:#a0845a;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="70%" style="stop-color:#8b6f47;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#6b5437;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="grooveGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#a85858;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#8b4545;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#a85858;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="wombatFur" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#8b7355;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#6b5a45;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#4a3f2f;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <filter id="shadow">
      <feGaussianBlur in="SourceAlpha" stdDeviation="3"/>
      <feOffset dx="2" dy="2" result="offsetblur"/>
      <feComponentTransfer>
        <feFuncA type="linear" slope="0.3"/>
      </feComponentTransfer>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
    
    <pattern id="texture" x="0" y="0" width="4" height="4" patternUnits="userSpaceOnUse">
      <circle cx="2" cy="2" r="0.5" fill="#000" opacity="0.03"/>
    </pattern>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- Background -->
  <rect width="800" height="600" fill="url(#parchment)"/>
  <rect width="800" height="600" fill="url(#texture)"/>
  
  <!-- Decorative border -->
  <rect x="10" y="10" width="780" height="580" fill="none" stroke="#8b6f47" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.4"/>
  
  <!-- Anatomical diagram section -->
  <g transform="translate(100, 80)">
    <!-- Intestine cross-section -->
    <!-- Outer wall -->
    <ellipse cx="250" cy="150" rx="180" ry="120" fill="url(#intestineWall)" stroke="#8b6f47" stroke-width="1.5"/>
    
    <!-- Inner wall -->
    <ellipse cx="250" cy="150" rx="150" ry="90" fill="url(#intestineInner)" stroke="#c89898" stroke-width="1"/>
    
    <!-- Groove regions (darker compressed areas) -->
    <path d="M 250 60 Q 220 80, 210 100 L 210 200 Q 220 220, 250 240" 
          fill="url(#grooveGradient)" stroke="#6b3838" stroke-width="1.5"/>
    <path d="M 250 60 Q 280 80, 290 100 L 290 200 Q 280 220, 250 240" 
          fill="url(#grooveGradient)" stroke="#6b3838" stroke-width="1.5"/>
    
    <!-- Central waste material showing cube formation -->
    <g transform="translate(250, 150)">
      <!-- Early stage - soft -->
      <ellipse cx="-100" cy="0" rx="25" ry="20" fill="#a0845a" opacity="0.7"/>
      
      <!-- Middle stage - forming -->
      <rect x="-50" y="-18" width="35" height="36" rx="3" fill="url(#wasteGradient)" opacity="0.85"/>
      
      <!-- Final stage - cube -->
      <g transform="translate(20, -15)">
        <!-- 3D cube representation -->
        <path d="M 0 15 L 15 5 L 30 15 L 30 30 L 15 40 L 0 30 Z" 
              fill="#6b5437" stroke="#4a3620" stroke-width="1"/>
        <path d="M 0 15 L 15 5 L 15 20 L 0 30 Z" 
              fill="#8b6f47" stroke="#4a3620" stroke-width="1"/>
        <path d="M 15 5 L 30 15 L 30 30 L 15 20 Z" 
              fill="#5a4832" stroke="#4a3620" stroke-width="1"/>
      </g>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Muscle fiber lines -->
    <path d="M 100 100 Q 110 120, 105 140" stroke="#a85858" stroke-width="1" fill="none" opacity="0.6"/>
    <path d="M 110 90 Q 120 110, 115 130" stroke="#a85858" stroke-width="1" fill="none" opacity="0.6"/>
    <path d="M 390 100 Q 380 120, 385 140" stroke="#a85858" stroke-width="1" fill="none" opacity="0.6"/>
    <path d="M 380 90 Q 370 110, 375 130" stroke="#a85858" stroke-width="1" fill="none" opacity="0.6"/>
    
    <!-- Percentage markers -->
    <g transform="translate(180, 60)">
      <circle cx="0" cy="0" r="18" fill="#8b6f47" opacity="0.8"/>
      <text x="0" y="1" text-anchor="middle" dominant-baseline="middle" 
            fill="#f5e6d3" font-family="serif" font-size="11" font-weight="bold">92%</text>
    </g>
    
    <g transform="translate(320, 60)">
      <circle cx="0" cy="0" r="18" fill="#6b3838" opacity="0.9"/>
      <text x="0" y="1" text-anchor="middle" dominant-baseline="middle" 
            fill="#f5e6d3" font-family="serif" font-size="11" font-weight="bold">8%</text>
    </g>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Wombat illustration -->
  <g transform="translate(480, 350)" filter="url(#shadow)">
    <!-- Body -->
    <ellipse cx="60" cy="40" rx="55" ry="45" fill="url(#wombatFur)" stroke="#3a2f1f" stroke-width="1.5"/>
    
    <!-- Head -->
    <ellipse cx="20" cy="25" rx="30" ry="28" fill="url(#wombatFur)" stroke="#3a2f1f" stroke-width="1.5"/>
    
    <!-- Ears -->
    <ellipse cx="10" cy="10" rx="8" ry="10" fill="#6b5a45" stroke="#3a2f1f" stroke-width="1"/>
    <ellipse cx="30" cy="8" rx="8" ry="10" fill="#6b5a45" stroke="#3a2f1f" stroke-width="1"/>
    
    <!-- Nose -->
    <ellipse cx="8" cy="30" rx="6" ry="5" fill="#4a3f2f" stroke="#2a1f1f" stroke-width="1"/>
    
    <!-- Eye -->
    <circle cx="18" cy="22" r="3" fill="#2a1f1f"/>
    
    <!-- Legs -->
    <ellipse cx="35" cy="75" rx="12" ry="15" fill="#6b5a45" stroke="#3a2f1f" stroke-width="1"/>
    <ellipse cx="75" cy="75" rx="12" ry="15" fill="#6b5a45" stroke="#3a2f1f" stroke-width="1"/>
    
    <!-- Back leg visible -->
    <ellipse cx="95" cy="70" rx="10" ry="13" fill="#4a3f2f" stroke="#3a2f1f" stroke-width="1"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Rocky terrain -->
  <g transform="translate(450, 440)">
    <ellipse cx="80" cy="40" rx="90" ry="20" fill="#a89878" opacity="0.5"/>
    <path d="M 20 35 L 35 30 L 50 38 L 45 45 Z" fill="#8b8070" stroke="#6b6050" stroke-width="1"/>
    <path d="M 100 32 L 120 28 L 135 35 L 125 42 Z" fill="#9b9080" stroke="#7b7060" stroke-width="1"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Cubic droppings stack -->
  <g transform="translate(520, 425)">
    <!-- Bottom cube -->
    <g>
      <path d="M 0 20 L 12 12 L 24 20 L 24 32 L 12 40 L 0 32 Z" 
            fill="#6b5437" stroke="#4a3620" stroke-width="1.5"/>
      <path d="M 0 20 L 12 12 L 12 24 L 0 32 Z" 
            fill="#8b6f47" stroke="#4a3620" stroke-width="1.5"/>
      <path d="M 12 12 L 24 20 L 24 32 L 12 24 Z" 
            fill="#5a4832" stroke="#4a3620" stroke-width="1.5"/>
      <!-- Shadow edge -->
      <line x1="2" y1="31" x2="10" y2="36" stroke="#2a1f10" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.3"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Middle cube -->
    <g transform="translate(2, -18)">
      <path d="M 0 20 L 12 12 L 24 20 L 24 32 L 12 40 L 0 32 Z" 
            fill="#6b5437" stroke="#4a3620" stroke-width="1.5"/>
      <path d="M 0 20 L 12 12 L 12 24 L 0 32 Z" 
            fill="#8b6f47" stroke="#4a3620" stroke-width="1.5"/>
      <path d="M 12 12 L 24 20 L 24 32 L 12 24 Z" 
            fill="#5a4832" stroke="#4a3620" stroke-width="1.5"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Top cube -->
    <g transform="translate(4, -36)">
      <path d="M 0 20 L 12 12 L 24 20 L 24 32 L 12 40 L 0 32 Z" 
            fill="#6b5437" stroke="#4a3620" stroke-width="1.5"/>
      <path d="M 0 20 L 12 12 L 12 24 L 0 32 Z"

  <!-- Dotted connection lines -->

  <line x1="350" y1="250" x2="540" y2="400" stroke="#8b6f47" stroke-width="1.5"

  <!-- Decorative corner elements -->

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory and prevent the droppings from rolling away. Scientists discovered in 2021 that this unique shape is formed in the last portion of their intestines, where varying elasticity of the intestinal walls molds the poop into cubes over several days of digestion.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces through differential elasticity in their intestinal walls, and they are indeed the only known animals to produce cubic feces, which they use as territorial markers that resist rolling.
facts.image_description: The illustration should be a split-panel scientific diagram in a naturalistic yet slightly stylized educational style, with warm earth tones dominating. The left panel shows a cross-sectional anatomical view of a wombat's digestive system in soft pinks and reds, with the intestinal walls clearly labeled and color-coded to show varying elasticity zones (darker reds for rigid sections, lighter pinks for flexible areas), while animated arrows demonstrate how the feces gradually transforms from cylindrical to cubic shape. The right panel depicts a photorealistic Australian bushland scene at golden hour, where a sturdy brown wombat is positioned near a rock, with several perfect cube-shaped droppings stacked like tiny brown dice on a prominent log or boulder, their geometric edges catching the warm sunset light to emphasize their remarkable angular shape against the organic wilderness backdrop.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <!-- Background -->
