  <!-- Dividing line -->
  <line x1="400" y1="0" x2="400" y2="600" stroke="#8b6f47" stroke-width="3"/>
  
  <!-- LEFT PANEL: Anatomical Cross-section -->
  <g id="anatomical-panel">
    <!-- Background gradient for left panel -->
    <defs>
      <radialGradient id="organBg" cx="50%" cy="50%">
        <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffd4d4;stop-opacity:1"/>
        <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ffb3b3;stop-opacity:1"/>
      </radialGradient>
      
      <linearGradient id="intestineGrad1" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
        <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#c94444;stop-opacity:1"/>
        <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#e07070;stop-opacity:1"/>
      </linearGradient>
      
      <linearGradient id="intestineGrad2" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
        <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#e07070;stop-opacity:1"/>
        <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ffb3b3;stop-opacity:1"/>
      </linearGradient>
      
      <linearGradient id="intestineGrad3" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
        <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffb3b3;stop-opacity:1"/>
        <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ffc9c9;stop-opacity:1"/>
      </linearGradient>
    </defs>
    
    <!-- Wombat silhouette outline -->
    <ellipse cx="200" cy="180" rx="100" ry="70" fill="#8b6f47" opacity="0.2"/>
    <circle cx="250" cy="160" r="45" fill="#8b6f47" opacity="0.2"/>
    
    <!-- Digestive tract - starting section -->
    <path d="M 100 150 Q 120 180 140 200" stroke="#e07070" stroke-width="35" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
    
    <!-- Middle intestine section - varying elasticity zones -->
    <ellipse cx="170" cy="250" rx="80" ry="50" fill="url(#intestineGrad1)" opacity="0.8"/>
    <rect x="130" y="220" width="80" height="60" rx="10" fill="url(#intestineGrad2)" opacity="0.7"/>
    
    <!-- Rigid section (darker red) -->
    <rect x="90" y="300" width="100" height="45" rx="8" fill="#c94444"/>
    <rect x="95" y="305" width="90" height="35" rx="6" fill="#d95555"/>
    
    <!-- Flexible section (lighter pink) -->
    <rect x="90" y="360" width="100" height="45" rx="8" fill="url(#intestineGrad3)"/>
    <rect x="95" y="365" width="90" height="35" rx="6" fill="#ffd4d4"/>
    
    <!-- Final shaping section with grid pattern -->
    <rect x="90" y="420" width="100" height="50" rx="8" fill="#ffb3b3"/>
    <path d="M 90 445 L 190 445 M 115 420 L 115 470 M 165 420 L 165 470" stroke="#e07070" stroke-width="2"/>
    
    <!-- Transformation arrows and shapes -->

    <ellipse cx="270" cy="250" rx="18" ry="25" fill="#8b5a3c" opacity="0.8"/>
    <rect x="252" y="225" width="36" height="50" fill="#8b5a3c" opacity="0.8"/>
    <ellipse cx="270" cy="225" rx="18" ry="8" fill="#6d4830" opacity="0.8"/>
    
    <!-- Arrow 1 -->
    <path d="M 290 260 L 310 280" stroke="#4a4a4a" stroke-width="3" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
    <defs>
      <marker id="arrowhead" markerWidth="10" markerHeight="10" refX="9" refY="3" orient="auto">
        <polygon points="0 0, 10 3, 0 6" fill="#4a4a4a"/>

    </defs>
    
    <!-- Intermediate shape -->

    <!-- Arrow 2 -->
    <path d="M 290 355 L 310 375" stroke="#4a4a4a" stroke-width="3" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
    
    <!-- Final cubic shape -->

    <!-- Cube-shaped droppings on log with 3D effect -->

facts.text: Zombie fires can smolder underground in Arctic peat for an entire winter, surviving temperatures of -40°F without any visible flames, then resurface months later to ignite new wildfires in the spring. These fires essentially hibernate beneath the snow, slowly consuming ancient carbon-rich soil that has been frozen for thousands of years.
facts.verification_note: Scientific research has documented that zombie fires (holdover fires) can indeed smolder in carbon-rich peat layers beneath snow through Arctic winters at extreme cold temperatures and re-emerge in spring, consuming ancient organic matter that releases stored carbon.
facts.image_description: A split-view cross-section illustration in a semi-realistic scientific style showing the Arctic landscape in two seasons: the left half depicts winter with pristine white snow covering the surface under dim twilight blues and purples, while beneath, an eerie orange-red glow permeates the dark brown peat layers like veins of lava, with wisps of smoke trapped in the soil's cavities. The right half shows spring thaw with the same underground fire now erupting through melting snow as bright yellow-orange flames, with charred black peat exposed and fresh green tundra vegetation at the edges beginning to catch fire. Thin white timeline arrows connect the two halves underground, showing the fire's persistent path through the frozen months, while small labels indicate temperature readings (-40°F) and the ancient, stratified layers of peat built up over millennia. The color palette dramatically contrasts the cold blues and whites of the Arctic surface with the warm, menacing glow of the hidden inferno below, creating an unsettling revelation of invisible danger.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory and prevent them from rolling away. Scientists discovered in 2021 that this unique shape is created by the varying elasticity of the wombat's intestinal walls, which mold the droppings into cubes during the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces through varying elasticity in their intestinal walls during the final portion of digestion, and they do use these distinctive droppings to mark territory on rocks and logs where the cubic shape prevents rolling.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional view in scientific illustration style, showing a wombat in profile on the left side with a transparent cutaway revealing its intestinal tract, highlighted in soft pinks and corals with the final 8% section glowing in amber to emphasize where the cube formation occurs. The right side should show a magnified, detailed view of the intestinal walls with varying thicknesses and elasticity represented by gradient shading from deep rose to pale cream, with directional arrows showing how the walls compress the feces into geometric cube shapes. In the foreground, a stack of perfectly formed, dark brown cube-shaped droppings should be arranged on rocky terrain under natural daylight, with one cube mid-formation still partially inside the transparent intestine, connected by a dotted line to show the transformation process. The color palette should blend scientific accuracy with visual appeal—earthy browns and grays for the wombat's fur, clinical anatomical colors for the organs, and warm golden lighting that makes the educational content inviting rather than clinical.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <linearGradient id="skyGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#e8f4f8;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#b8d4e0;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="intestineGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#f4a6b8;stop-opacity:0.7" />
      <stop offset="80%" style="stop-color:#f4a6b8;stop-opacity:0.7" />
      <stop offset="92%" style="stop-color:#f5b35a;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#f5b35a;stop-opacity:0.9" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="wallGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#c94a6d;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#f4a6b8;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#f9e8d9;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="wombatFur" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#6b5d52;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#4a3f36;stop-opacity:1" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="cubeGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#5c4033;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#4a3328;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#3a261c;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <filter id="glow">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="4" result="coloredBlur"/>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
    
    <marker id="arrowhead" markerWidth="10" markerHeight="10" refX="9" refY="3" orient="auto">
      <polygon points="0 0, 10 3, 0 6" fill="#c94a6d" />
    </marker>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- Background -->
  <rect width="800" height="600" fill="url(#skyGradient)"/>
  
  <!-- Ground -->
  <path d="M 0 450 Q 200 430 400 450 T 800 450 L 800 600 L 0 600 Z" fill="#8b7355"/>
  <path d="M 0 470 Q 200 460 400 470 T 800 475 L 800 600 L 0 600 Z" fill="#7a6347"/>
  
  <!-- Rocky terrain details -->
  <ellipse cx="150" cy="480" rx="40" ry="15" fill="#5a5045" opacity="0.6"/>
  <ellipse cx="320" cy="490" rx="35" ry="12" fill="#5a5045" opacity="0.6"/>
  <ellipse cx="500" cy="485" rx="45" ry="18" fill="#5a5045" opacity="0.6"/>
  
  <!-- Wombat body -->
  <ellipse cx="180" cy="340" rx="85" ry="75" fill="url(#wombatFur)"/>
  
  <!-- Wombat head -->
  <ellipse cx="100" cy="310" rx="50" ry="45" fill="url(#wombatFur)"/>
  
  <!-- Wombat ear -->
  <ellipse cx="85" cy="285" rx="15" ry="20" fill="#5a4d42"/>
  
  <!-- Wombat nose -->
  <ellipse cx="65" cy="315" rx="12" ry="10" fill="#3a261c"/>
  
  <!-- Wombat eye -->
  <circle cx="90" cy="305" r="5" fill="#2a1a10"/>
  
  <!-- Wombat legs -->
  <ellipse cx="140" cy="400" rx="20" ry="30" fill="#5a4d42"/>
  <ellipse cx="200" cy="400" rx="20" ry="30" fill="#5a4d42"/>
  
  <!-- Transparent intestinal tract -->
  <path d="M 120 320 Q 140 330 160 335 Q 200 340 220 350 Q 240 360 245 380 Q 248 400 240 420 Q 230 440 220 455" 
        stroke="url(#intestineGradient)" stroke-width="20" fill="none" opacity="0.8"/>
  
  <!-- Glowing final section -->
  <path d="M 240 420 Q 230 440 220 455" 
        stroke="#f5b35a" stroke-width="22" fill="none" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#glow)"/>
  
  <!-- Cube mid-formation inside intestine -->
  <g transform="translate(220, 445)">
    <rect x="-8" y="-8" width="16" height="16" fill="#5c4033" opacity="0.6"/>
    <polygon points="-8,-8 0,-12 8,-8 8,8 0,12 -8,8" fill="#4a3328" opacity="0.6"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Dotted line to cube stack -->
  <line x1="220" y1="455" x2="280" y2="480" stroke="#f5b35a" stroke-width="2" stroke-dasharray="5,5" opacity="0.7"/>
  
  <!-- Magnified intestinal wall view (right side) -->
  <rect x="520" y="150" width="240" height="200" fill="#f9f5f0" stroke="#c94a6d" stroke-width="2" rx="10"/>
  
  <!-- Intestinal wall layers with varying thickness -->
  <path d="M 540 180 Q 580 190 620 180 Q 660 170 700 185 L 700 220 Q 660 230 620 220 Q 580 210 540 225 Z" 
        fill="url(#wallGradient)" opacity="0.8"/>
  <path d="M 540 240 Q 590 235 640 245 Q 690 250 740 240 L 740 280 Q 690 295 640 285 Q 590 275 540 285 Z" 
        fill="url(#wallGradient)" opacity="0.8"/>
  <path d="M 540 300 Q 580 310 620 300 Q 660 290 700 305 L 700 330 Q 660 325 620 330 Q 580 335 540 325 Z" 
        fill="url(#wallGradient)" opacity="0.8"/>
  
  <!-- Compression arrows -->
  <line x1="545" y1="200" x2="600" y2="200" stroke="#c94a6d" stroke-width="3" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
  <line x1="735" y1="200" x2="680" y2="200" stroke="#c94a6d" stroke-width="3" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
  
  <line x1="545" y1="260" x2="610" y2="260" stroke="#c94a6d" stroke-width="3" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
  <line x1="735" y1="260" x2="670" y2="260" stroke="#c94a6d" stroke-width="3" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
  
  <line x1="545" y1="315" x2="600" y2="315" stroke="#c94a6d" stroke-width="3" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
  <line x1="735" y1="315" x2="680" y2="315" stroke="#c94a6d" stroke-width="3" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
  
  <!-- Forming cube in magnified view -->
  <g transform="translate(640, 260)">
    <rect x="-15" y="-15" width="30" height="30" fill="url(#cubeGradient)" opacity="0.7"/>
    <polygon points="-15,-15 0,-20 15,-15 15,15 0,20 -15,15" fill="#5c4033" opacity="0.5"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Stack of cube-shaped droppings on terrain -->
  <g transform="translate(280, 460)">
    <!-- Bottom cube -->
    <rect x="0" y="20" width="28" height="28" fill="url(#cubeGradient)"/>
    <polygon points="0,20 14,14 42,14 28,20 28,48 14,54 0,48" fill="#4a3328"/>
    <polygon points="28,20 42,14 42,42 28,48" fill="#3a261c"/>
    
    <!-- Middle cube -->
    <rect x="0" y="-8" width="28" height="28" fill="url(#cubeGradient)"/>
    <polygon points="0,-8 14,-14 42,-14 28,-8 28,20 14,26 0,20" fill="#4a3328"/>
    <polygon points="28,-8 42,-14 42,14 28,20" fill="#3a261c"/>
    
    <!-- Top cube -->

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory and prevent the droppings from rolling away. Scientists discovered this happens because of the unique elasticity of the wombat's intestinal walls, which have regions of varying stiffness that literally sculpt the poop into cubes during the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces through varying elasticity in their intestinal walls during the final portion of digestion, and they do use these cubes as territorial markers that resist rolling.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional view of a wombat in profile, rendered in a semi-transparent anatomical style with warm earth tones (browns, tans, and soft pinks for internal organs). The digestive tract should be prominently highlighted, showing the final portion of the intestine with color-coded regions indicating varying stiffness levels (using a gradient from deep burgundy for stiff areas to pale pink for elastic areas), with small arrows demonstrating how these zones compress the feces into cubic shapes. In the foreground, a photorealistic wombat should be shown actively stacking several perfectly geometric, dark brown cube-shaped droppings on a rocky outcrop, while the background features soft, dappled Australian bushland lighting. Small inset diagrams in scientific illustration style should show the progressive transformation from round to cubic shape through the final 8% of the intestinal journey, with percentage markers and dimensional measurements to emphasize the precision of this biological phenomenon.

facts.text: Octopuses have three hearts and blue blood, but even stranger: their neurons are distributed throughout their eight arms, meaning each arm can taste, touch, and even make decisions independently while a severed arm will continue trying to grab food and bring it to where the mouth used to be for hours after detachment.
facts.verification_note: Scientific research confirms octopuses have three hearts, copper-based blue blood (hemocyanin), approximately two-thirds of their neurons distributed in their arms which can taste and act semi-independently, and severed arms do exhibit reflexive food-grasping behavior for extended periods post-detachment.
facts.image_description: A semi-translucent octopus rendered in scientific illustration style floats against a deep ocean blue-black gradient, its body revealing three glowing crimson hearts pumping luminescent blue blood through visible veins. The eight arms spread outward in a radial composition, each one embedded with golden-orange neural networks that pulse like fiber optic cables beneath the skin, with one severed arm in the lower corner still actively reaching toward a small fish, its neurons still glowing despite separation. The lighting creates an ethereal X-ray effect, highlighting the distributed brain system as a constellation of bioluminescent nodes along each tentacle, while microscopic suction cups are shown in detailed cross-section, revealing both touch and taste receptors as jewel-like structures in amber and violet hues.

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory and prevent the droppings from rolling away. Scientists discovered in 2021 that this happens because wombat intestines have varying elasticity in different sections, with stiff and flexible regions that mold the poop into cubes during the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to varying intestinal elasticity that forms the shape in the final portion of digestion, and they do use these distinctive droppings to mark territory on rocks and logs where round feces would roll off.
facts.image_description: The illustration shows a cross-sectional scientific diagram in warm earth tones, depicting a wombat's digestive tract in translucent amber and pink hues against a soft twilight blue background. The intestinal walls are rendered in detailed anatomical style, with color-coded regions showing stiff sections in deep burgundy and flexible areas in soft peach, with arrows indicating how these varying elasticities sculpt the waste into distinctive cube shapes. In the foreground, a photorealistic wombat stands proudly beside a small stack of its geometric droppings arranged like wooden blocks on rocky Australian terrain, while an inset magnification bubble shows the precise 8% final section of the intestine where the cubic transformation occurs, complete with measurement indicators and directional force arrows in scientific diagram style.

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory and prevent the droppings from rolling away. Their intestines have varying elasticity at different points, with sections of stiffer tissue that mold the waste into distinctive cubes over the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Scientific research has confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces through differential elasticity in their intestinal walls during the final portion of digestion, and they use these distinctive droppings to mark territory on rocks and logs where round feces would roll off.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional scientific diagram in a naturalistic style, showing a wombat's lower digestive tract with transparent overlays revealing the intestinal walls in soft pinks and mauves. The intestines should display visible bands of darker, stiffer tissue (in deep rose tones) alternating with more elastic, lighter sections, with arrows indicating how these varying tensions gradually shape the waste from round to angular to perfectly cubic. In the foreground, a photorealistic wombat should be positioned near a rocky outcrop at golden-hour lighting, with a neat stack of cube-shaped droppings in rich browns visible on a flat stone surface, demonstrating the territorial marking behavior. Small measurement annotations and percentage markers (highlighting the "final 8%") should appear in clean, modern typography alongside the anatomical section, giving it the polished look of a contemporary nature documentary infographic.

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory. Scientists discovered in 2021 that this unusual shape is created by varying elasticity in the wombat's intestinal walls, with stiffer regions forming the corners and softer regions forming the flatter sides.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to differential elasticity in their intestinal walls, and they do stack these cubes to mark territory, making them unique among animals in this regard.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional scientific diagram in a modern, clean educational style, showing a wombat in profile on the left third with its digestive system visible through a cutaway view. The intestinal walls should be rendered in warm peachy-pink tones with clearly labeled regions showing varying tissue elasticity—darker coral-red for stiffer sections that form cube corners, and lighter salmon-pink for softer areas creating flat sides. In the foreground, several perfectly geometric brown cube-shaped droppings should be arranged in a small stack on Australian bush terrain with eucalyptus leaves and golden afternoon lighting. Small detail callouts with clean lines should point to the intestinal wall variations, while the overall composition balances scientific accuracy with engaging visual storytelling, using a color palette of earth tones, soft greens, and clinical anatomical pinks against a subtle cream background.

      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ff7a68;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    <radialGradient id="cubeGradient" cx="40%" cy="40%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#8b6f47;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#5c4a30;stop-opacity:1" />
    </radialGradient>
    <linearGradient id="groundGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#c9a876;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#a88d5f;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- Background -->
  <rect width="800" height="600" fill="url(#bgGradient)"/>
  
  <!-- Ground -->
  <ellipse cx="650" cy="520" rx="180" ry="40" fill="url(#groundGradient)" opacity="0.6"/>
  
  <!-- Eucalyptus leaves scattered -->
  <ellipse cx="580" cy="510" rx="15" ry="5" fill="#7a9b6f" opacity="0.7" transform="rotate(-20 580 510)"/>
  <ellipse cx="720" cy="515" rx="18" ry="6" fill="#8aab7f" opacity="0.7" transform="rotate(35 720 515)"/>
  <ellipse cx="640" cy="525" rx="12" ry="4" fill="#6a8b5f" opacity="0.7" transform="rotate(-45 640 525)"/>
  
  <!-- Wombat body -->
  <ellipse cx="200" cy="280" rx="120" ry="90" fill="url(#wombatFur)"/>
  
  <!-- Wombat head -->
  <ellipse cx="90" cy="250" rx="60" ry="55" fill="url(#wombatFur)"/>
  
  <!-- Wombat ear -->
  <ellipse cx="70" cy="220" rx="18" ry="25" fill="#6b5845"/>
  
  <!-- Wombat nose -->
  <ellipse cx="50" cy="255" rx="12" ry="10" fill="#4a3825"/>
  
  <!-- Wombat eye -->
  <circle cx="75" cy="245" r="5" fill="#2a2520"/>
  
  <!-- Wombat legs -->
  <ellipse cx="150" cy="350" rx="25" ry="35" fill="#6b5845"/>
  <ellipse cx="220" cy="350" rx="25" ry="35" fill="#6b5845"/>
  
  <!-- Cutaway section background -->
  <ellipse cx="200" cy="280" rx="90" ry="70" fill="#f5e6d9" opacity="0.9"/>
  
  <!-- Digestive system - intestinal path -->
  <path d="M 200 200 Q 220 230 210 260 Q 200 290 220 320 Q 240 340 250 360" 
        stroke="#ff8c7a" stroke-width="35" fill="none" opacity="0.8"/>
  
  <!-- Intestinal wall sections with varying elasticity -->
  <!-- Stiff section (corner forming) - top -->
  <path d="M 200 200 Q 220 230 210 250" 
        stroke="url(#intestineStiff)" stroke-width="38" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
  
  <!-- Soft section (flat side) -->
  <path d="M 210 250 Q 200 270 210 290" 
        stroke="url(#intestineSoft)" stroke-width="38" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
  
  <!-- Stiff section (corner forming) - middle -->
  <path d="M 210 290 Q 220 310 230 325" 
        stroke="url(#intestineStiff)" stroke-width="38" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
  
  <!-- Soft section (flat side) -->
  <path d="M 230 325 Q 240 340 250 360" 
        stroke="url(#intestineSoft)" stroke-width="38" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
  
  <!-- Detail callout lines -->
  <!-- Callout to stiff region -->
  <line x1="205" y1="225" x2="280" y2="180" stroke="#d64545" stroke-width="2"/>
  <circle cx="280" cy="180" r="20" fill="#d64545" opacity="0.3"/>
  <circle cx="280" cy="180" r="15" fill="#d64545" opacity="0.5"/>
  
  <!-- Callout to soft region -->
  <line x1="210" y1="270" x2="290" y2="250" stroke="#ffb3a7" stroke-width="2"/>
  <circle cx="290" cy="250" r="20" fill="#ffb3a7" opacity="0.3"/>
  <circle cx="290" cy="250" r="15" fill="#ffb3a7" opacity="0.5"/>
  
  <!-- Callout to another stiff region -->
  <line x1="225" y1="310" x2="300" y2="320" stroke="#d64545" stroke-width="2"/>
  <circle cx="300" cy="320" r="20" fill="#d64545" opacity="0.3"/>
  <circle cx="300" cy="320" r="15" fill="#d64545" opacity="0.5"/>
  
  <!-- Cube-shaped droppings stack -->
  <!-- Bottom cube -->
  <g transform="translate(620, 480)">
    <!-- Top face -->
    <path d="M 0 0 L 30 -15 L 60 0 L 30 15 Z" fill="url(#cubeGradient)"/>
    <!-- Left face -->
    <path d="M 0 0 L 30 15 L 30 45 L 0 30 Z" fill="#5c4a30"/>
    <!-- Right face -->
    <path d="M 30 15 L 60 0 L 60 30 L 30 45 Z" fill="#6b5438"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Middle cube -->
  <g transform="translate(620, 440)">
    <path d="M 0 0 L 30 -15 L 60 0 L 30 15 Z" fill="url(#cubeGradient)"/>
    <path d="M 0 0 L 30 15 L 30 45 L 0 30 Z" fill="#5c4a30"/>
    <path d="M 30 15 L 60 0 L 60 30 L 30 45 Z" fill="#6b5438"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Top cube -->
  <g transform="translate(620, 400)">
    <path d="M 0 0 L 30 -15 L 60 0 L 30 15 Z" fill="url(#cubeGradient)"/>
    <path d="M 0 0 L 30 15 L 30 45 L 0 30 Z" fill="#5c4a30"/>
    <path d="M 30 15 L 60 0 L 60 30 L 30 45 Z" fill="#6b5438"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Single cube to the side -->
  <g transform="translate(680, 490)">
    <path d="M 0 0 L 25 -12 L 50 0 L 25 12 Z" fill="url(#cubeGradient)"/>
    <path d="M 0 0 L 25 12 L 25 37 L 0 25 Z" fill="#5c4a30"/>
    <path d="M 25 12 L 50 0 L 50 25 L 25 37 Z" fill="#6b5438"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Magnified cube detail -->
  <g transform="translate(500, 100)">
    <circle cx="60" cy="60" r="70" fill="white" opacity="0.8"/>
    <circle cx="60" cy="60" r="68" fill="none" stroke="#8b7355" stroke-width="2"/>
    
    <!-- Detailed cube showing corners and flats -->
    <g transform="translate(30, 30)">
      <path d="M 0 0 L 40 -20 L 80 0 L 40 20 Z" fill="#8b6f47"/>
      <path d="M 0 0 L 40 20 L 40 60 L 0 40 Z" fill="#5c4a30"/>
      <path d="M 40 20 L 80 0 L 80 40 L 40 60 Z" fill="#6b5438"/>
      
      <!-- Corner indicators -->

      <circle cx="40" cy="-20" r="4" fill="#d64545"/>

      <circle cx="40" cy="20" r="4" fill="#d64545"/>

  <!-- Connecting line from intestine to cubes -->
  <path d="M 250 360 Q 400 420 600 480" stroke="#8b7355" stroke-width="3" stroke-dasharray="5,5" fill="none" opacity="0.5"/>
  
  <!-- Scientific diagram elements -->
  <circle cx="200" cy="120" r="3" fill="#d64545"/>
  <circle cx="210" cy="125" r="3" fill="#ffb3a7"/>

</svg>

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory. Scientists discovered in 2021 that this unusual shape is created by the varying elasticity of the wombat's intestinal walls, which mold the poop into cubes during the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to varying elasticity in their intestinal walls during the final portion of digestion, and they do use these cubes to mark territory.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional anatomical view of a wombat's lower digestive system in a scientific illustration style, with the intestinal walls rendered in warm pinks and reds showing distinct zones of varying elasticity—some sections appearing more rigid and others more flexible. The focal point shows the gradual transformation of waste from round to distinctly cubic shapes as it moves through the final section of the intestine, with subtle arrows or gradient shading indicating the compression forces. In the background or corner, a realistic wombat is shown in its natural Australian bush habitat, surrounded by several perfectly stacked brown cube-shaped droppings on rocks, demonstrating the real-world result of this remarkable biological process. The lighting should be clean and clinical for the anatomical section while naturalistic and warm for the environmental portion, creating an engaging contrast between scientific detail and observable behavior.

facts.text: When you get a sunburn, you're not actually feeling the burn from UV radiation itself—you're feeling your own cells committing suicide. Your damaged skin cells detect the DNA destruction caused by UV rays and trigger apoptosis (programmed cell death) to prevent becoming cancerous, and it's this mass cellular suicide that causes the inflammation, redness, and pain.
facts.verification_note: UV radiation causes DNA damage in skin cells, which triggers apoptosis to prevent cancer, and the resulting inflammatory response from dying cells and immune system activation produces the characteristic redness, swelling, and pain of sunburn.
facts.image_description: The illustration should show a cross-section of human skin in a semi-transparent, scientific cutaway style with dramatic lighting. In the upper epidermis layer, individual skin cells glow an ominous red-orange as they undergo apoptosis, their nuclei fragmenting like shattered glass with visible DNA strands breaking apart, while healthy cells below remain a cool blue-white. Golden UV rays pierce down from above like deadly spotlights, and the damaged zone should be surrounded by an inflammatory halo of pink and red, with tiny illustrated immune cells (shown as small spheres) rushing toward the suicide zone. The style should blend medical textbook precision with slightly stylized, almost cinematic drama—using a dark background to make the glowing cellular destruction pop, with perhaps a subtle silhouette of a person's shoulder in the background to ground the microscopic action in human scale.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">

      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ffa000;stop-opacity:0.3" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="damagedCell" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ff6b35;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#ff4500;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#cc0000;stop-opacity:0.6" />
    </radialGradient>

      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#0097a7;stop-opacity:0.5" />

    </radialGradient>
    
    <filter id="glow">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="3" result="coloredBlur"/>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>

    </filter>
    
    <filter id="strongGlow">

      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>

  <!-- UV rays from top -->

    <path d="M 550 0 L 570 180 L 530 180 Z" fill="url(#uvRay)" filter="url(#strongGlow)"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Skin cross-section container -->
  <path d="M 50 150 Q 400 120 750 150 L 750 500 Q 400 520 50 500 Z" fill="url(#skinGrad)" opacity="0.6" stroke="#d4a574" stroke-width="2"/>
  
  <!-- Epidermis layer boundary -->
  <path d="M 80 250 Q 400 240 720 250" stroke="#c89968" stroke-width="1.5" fill="none" opacity="0.5" stroke-dasharray="5,5"/>
  
  <!-- Inflammation halos in damaged zone -->

  <ellipse cx="450" cy="210" rx="160" ry="80" fill="url(#inflammation)" filter="url(#glow)"/>
  
  <!-- Damaged cells undergoing apoptosis (upper layer) -->
  <g id="damagedCells">
    <!-- Cell 1 -->
    <ellipse cx="200" cy="190" rx="28" ry="26" fill="url(#damagedCell)" filter="url(#strongGlow)" opacity="0.9"/>

    <path d="M 275 195 L 285 205 M 285 195 L 275 205 M 280 192 L 280 208" stroke="#ffeb3b" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.7"/>
    <line x1="270" y1="195" x2="262" y2="188" stroke="#ff8a65" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.6"/>
    <line x1="290" y1="195" x2="298" y2="188" stroke="#ff8a65" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.6"/>
    
    <!-- Cell 3 -->
    <ellipse cx="360" cy="195" rx="26" ry="25" fill="url(#damagedCell)" filter="url(#strongGlow)" opacity="0.9"/>
    <circle cx="360" cy="195" r="11" fill="#660000" opacity="0.8"/>

facts.text: Tardigrades, microscopic animals also known as water bears, can survive being frozen to nearly absolute zero (-272°C), heated to 150°C, exposed to the vacuum of space, and blasted with radiation levels hundreds of times higher than what would kill a human. When conditions become inhospitable, they expel almost all water from their bodies, retract their legs, and enter a state called cryptobiosis where their metabolism drops to 0.01% of normal, allowing them to survive for decades until rehydrated.
facts.verification_note: All stated claims about tardigrade survival capabilities, including extreme temperature tolerance, radiation resistance, space vacuum survival, and cryptobiotic state characteristics, are well-documented in peer-reviewed scientific literature.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a split-scene composition showing a magnified tardigrade as the central focus, rendered in detailed scientific illustration style with photorealistic textures. On the left side, show a plump, translucent tardigrade in its active state with visible segmented body, eight stubby legs with claws, and a soft peachy-pink coloration, surrounded by water droplets that catch light like tiny prisms. On the right side, show the same tardigrade in its cryptobiotic "tun" state—shriveled into a barrel shape with legs retracted, appearing darker and more amber-colored with a wrinkled, dehydrated texture. The background should feature four quadrants displaying extreme conditions: deep space's inky blackness with stars, crystalline ice formations in electric blues, glowing orange-red heat waves, and green radiation symbols with a Geiger counter aesthetic, all connected by subtle geometric lines suggesting scientific measurement and observation.

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory and prevent them from rolling away. Scientists discovered this happens because of the varying elasticity of the wombat's intestinal walls, with stiffer regions forming the edges and softer regions forming the flat sides of each cube.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2018-2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to differential elasticity in their intestinal walls, and they do use these cubes to mark territory, with the shape preventing rolling on uneven terrain.
facts.image_description: A cross-sectional scientific illustration showing a wombat in profile with a translucent view of its digestive system, revealing the intestinal walls in graduated colors—deep rose-pink for softer, more elastic regions and amber-gold for stiffer areas—creating a geometric pattern that demonstrates how the cube shapes form. In the foreground, several perfectly formed, dark brown cubic feces are artistically stacked on a moss-covered rock or log, with subtle shadows emphasizing their sharp edges and flat surfaces. The style blends photorealistic detail for the wombat's fur texture and anatomical accuracy with educational diagram aesthetics, using a soft, diffused natural lighting that suggests an Australian bush setting at golden hour, with eucalyptus leaves subtly blurred in the background to provide context without distraction.

  </g>
  
  <!-- Moss-covered log/rock -->

  <path d="M 150 490 Q 180 470 220 475 Q 260 480 300 470 Q 340 460 380 475 Q 400 485 410 510 L 400 530 Q 380 540 340 545 Q 300 548 260 545 Q 220 542 180 535 Q 150 525 150 490 Z" fill="#6b5b4b" filter="url(#shadow)"/>

  <ellipse cx="350" cy="505" rx="18" ry="7" fill="#5a7a4a" opacity="0.7"/>
  
  <!-- Wombat body -->
  <g id="wombat">
    <!-- Main body -->
    <ellipse cx="480" cy="340" rx="140" ry="100" fill="url(#furGradient)" filter="url(#shadow)"/>

    <path d="M 450 340 Q 460 360 480 370" stroke="url(#intestineAmber)" stroke-width="18" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
    <path d="M 480 370 Q 500 375 520 370" stroke="url(#intestineRose)" stroke-width="18" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
    <path d="M 520 370 Q 535 360 540 340" stroke="url(#intestineAmber)" stroke-width="18" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
    <path d="M 540 340 Q 545 320 535 300" stroke="url(#intestineRose)" stroke-width="18" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
    <path d="M 535 300 Q 525 285 510 280" stroke="url(#intestineAmber)" stroke-width="18" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
    
    <!-- Geometric pattern showing cube formation zones -->
    <rect x="475" y="365" width="12" height="12" fill="#e8a550" opacity="0.6" transform="rotate(15 481 371)"/>
    <rect x="535" y="335" width="12" height="12" fill="#e8a550" opacity="0.6" transform="rotate(-20 541 341)"/>
    <rect x="530" y="295" width="12" height="12" fill="#e8a550" opacity="0.6" transform="rotate(10 536 301)"/>
    
    <circle cx="455" cy="345" r="6" fill="#d96b8a" opacity="0.6"/>
    <circle cx="520" cy="375" r="6" fill="#d96b8a" opacity="0.6"/>
    <circle cx="540" cy="305" r="6" fill="#d96b8a" opacity="0.6"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Cubic feces stacked on log -->
  <g id="cubicFeces">
    <!-- Back cube -->
    <g transform="translate(250, 460)">
      <polygon points="0,20 20,10 40,20 40,50 20,60 0,50" fill="url(#cubeGradient)" filter="url(#shadow)"/>
      <polygon points="20,10 40,20 40,50 20,40" fill="#3d2b1f" opacity="0.8"/>
      <polygon points="0,20 20,10 20,40 0,50" fill="#4a3528" opacity="0.8"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Middle cube -->
    <g transform="translate(280, 450)">
      <polygon points="0,20 22,8 44,20 44,52 22,64 0,52" fill="url(#cubeGradient)" filter="url(#shadow)"/>

      <polygon points="0,20 22,8 22,40 0,52" fill="#4a3528" opacity="0.8"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Front cube -->
    <g transform="translate(310, 465)">
      <polygon points="0,18 20,8 40,18 40,48 20,58 0,48" fill="url(#cubeGradient)" filter="url(#shadow)"/>
      <polygon points="20,8 40,18 40,48 20,38" fill="#3d2b1f" opacity="0.9"/>
      <polygon points="0,18 20,8 20,38 0,48" fill="#4a3528" opacity="0.9"/>
      <!-- Sharp edge highlight -->
      <line x1="20" y1="8" x2="40" y2="18" stroke="#5a4232" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.7"/>
      <line x1="20" y1="8" x2="20" y2="38" stroke="#6a5242" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.5"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Additional cube on side -->
    <g transform="translate(220, 475)">
      <polygon points="0,15 18,6 36,15 36,43 18,52 0,43" fill="url(#cubeGradient)" filter="url(#shadow)"/>

    </g>

  <!-- Subtle ground shadow -->
  <ellipse cx="480" cy="440" rx="160" ry="20" fill="#000000" opacity="0.15"/>
</svg>

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory and prevent the droppings from rolling away. Scientists discovered this happens because wombat intestines have varying elasticity in different regions, with stiffer sections creating the flat sides and more flexible areas forming the corners during the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to varying intestinal elasticity that creates flat sides and corners in the final 8% of the intestine, and they do stack these droppings to mark territory on rocks and logs where round feces would roll off.
facts.image_description: A cutaway scientific illustration showing a wombat in profile with its digestive system visible through a translucent body, rendered in warm earth tones against a soft twilight background. The intestinal tract is color-coded with gradient blues and purples indicating varying elasticity levels, with the final section highlighted in amber to show where the cube formation occurs. In the foreground, a neat stack of geometrically perfect, dark brown cubic droppings sits on Australian red soil beside native grasses, with measurement indicators and small directional arrows showing how the cubes prevent rolling on sloped terrain. The style blends photorealistic animal rendering with technical medical illustration, using soft natural lighting that emphasizes both the wombat's fuzzy texture and the scientific precision of the anatomical details.

facts.text: A group of scientists discovered that wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they achieve through varying elasticity in their intestinal walls that molds the droppings into cubes during the final 8% of the digestive process. They stack these cubes on rocks and logs to mark territory, and the cubic shape prevents them from rolling away.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces through differential elasticity in their intestinal walls during the final portion of digestion, and they do use these cubes to mark territory on elevated surfaces where the shape prevents rolling.
facts.image_description: A detailed cross-sectional scientific illustration showing a wombat's digestive system in warm earth tones, with a transparent cutaway revealing the intestinal walls in varying shades of pink and coral. The intestines are labeled with arrows indicating zones of different elasticity, with the final section demonstrating how the walls compress the waste into distinct cubic corners. In the foreground, a photorealistic Australian wombat is shown stacking several dark brown, perfectly geometric cube-shaped droppings on a weathered grey log, with soft natural lighting filtering through eucalyptus trees in the background. Small detail callouts with magnified views show the precise 90-degree angles of the cubes and the textural differences in the intestinal tissue, rendered in the clean, precise style of a nature documentary or veterinary textbook.

facts.text: A group of scientists successfully unboiled an egg by using urea to untangle the proteins in cooked egg whites, then applying a vortex fluid device to refold them back to their original structure. This 2015 breakthrough won an Ig Nobel Prize and has serious implications for cancer research, as it could make protein production for drugs much cheaper and faster.
facts.verification_note: This accurately describes the 2015 UC Irvine and Flinders University research that won an Ig Nobel Prize, where researchers used urea and a vortex fluid device to refold boiled egg white proteins, with potential applications in reducing costs for cancer antibody production.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a split-screen scientific comparison in a clean, modern infographic style with a soft laboratory blue-white lighting scheme. On the left, a translucent cross-section of a hard-boiled egg white shows tangled, chaotic protein strands rendered in opaque white and pale yellow, while on the right, the same egg white appears clearer with neatly organized, spiral protein structures in luminous blue-green, connected by a central glowing vortex device with spinning motion lines. In the background, faded imagery of cancer cells and pharmaceutical vials suggests the broader implications, while small urea molecules (represented as geometric crystal shapes) float around the proteins like magical catalysts. The composition should balance scientific accuracy with an almost magical transformation aesthetic, using arrows and subtle glow effects to emphasize the "unboiling" process, making the impossible seem visually tangible and exciting.

facts.text: Zombie ants are real: a parasitic fungus called Ophiocordyceps unilateralis infects carpenter ants, takes control of their nervous system, and compels them to climb to an elevated location and bite down on a leaf or twig before killing them—positioning the ant's corpse in the perfect spot for the fungus to spread its spores to more victims below.
facts.verification_note: Ophiocordyceps unilateralis does infect carpenter ants and manipulates their behavior to climb to elevated locations where they perform a characteristic "death grip" bite, after which the fungus kills the ant and produces a fruiting body that releases spores to infect other ants below.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-section view of a rainforest understory in a scientific-yet-haunting style, showing three stages of infection: a healthy carpenter ant on the forest floor (reddish-brown and glossy), a zombie ant mid-climb on a tree trunk with visible fungal threads erupting from its leg joints (pale white mycelium contrasting against darkening exoskeleton), and a dead ant locked in its signature "death grip" on a leaf's underside with dramatic orange-brown fruiting bodies (the cordyceps stalk) exploding from its head and releasing a visible cloud of microscopic spores that drift downward in golden-green dappled sunlight. The composition should use a dark, moss-covered forest background with dramatic side-lighting that illuminates the spore cloud like dust motes, while cutaway sections reveal the fungal network threading through the zombie ant's brain and body in bioluminescent blue-white, creating an unsettling blend of nature documentary realism and body-horror detail. Small silhouettes of unsuspecting ants below should be visible in the spore's descent path, completing the cycle,

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">

      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#8b7355;stop-opacity:0"/>
    </radialGradient>

      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#0d1a0d"/>
    </linearGradient>

      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#2d1810"/>
    </linearGradient>

      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#9db86f;stop-opacity:0.3"/>

    </radialGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="fungalGlow" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#a0d8ff;stop-opacity:0.9"/>
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#4a90c8;stop-opacity:0.6"/>

        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>

  <!-- Tree trunk -->
  <path d="M 400 0 L 420 0 L 450 600 L 370 600 Z" fill="url(#treeTrunk)"/>
  
  <!-- Bark texture -->

  <!-- Moss on trunk -->

  <ellipse cx="425" cy="380" rx="12" ry="18" fill="#3d5c2d" opacity="0.5"/>
  
  <!-- STAGE 1: Healthy ant on forest floor -->
  <g transform="translate(150, 500)">

    <ellipse cx="0" cy="0" rx="8" ry="6" fill="#8b4513"/>
    <ellipse cx="-12" cy="-2" rx="6" ry="5" fill="#a0522d"/>

  <!-- STAGE 2: Zombie ant climbing with fungal threads -->

    <!-- Internal fungal network (cutaway view) -->

  <!-- Leaf at death grip location -->

    <path d="M 5 5 L 35 5" stroke="#2d4a2d" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.6"/>

    <path d="M 25 3 Q 30 5 25 7" stroke="#2d4a2d" stroke-width="0.5" opacity="0.5"/>

facts.text: Tardigrades, microscopic eight-legged animals, can survive being frozen to nearly absolute zero (-272°C), heated to 150°C, exposed to the vacuum of space, and blasted with radiation doses 1,000 times what would kill a human—and when conditions improve, they simply reanimate and continue living as if nothing happened. They achieve this by replacing almost all the water in their bodies with a glass-like sugar called trehalose and entering a state called cryptobiosis where their metabolism drops to 0.01% of normal.
facts.verification_note: Tardigrades can indeed survive these extreme conditions through cryptobiosis using trehalose and other protective molecules, though the radiation tolerance is actually even higher (up to 5,000-6,000 Gy compared to ~10 Gy lethal dose for humans), and they use additional mechanisms beyond just trehalose including unique proteins called Dsup and tardigrade-specific intrinsically disordered proteins.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a highly magnified tardigrade in crystalline suspended animation at the center, its translucent body glowing with an amber-gold luminescence as trehalose sugar molecules form geometric, glass-like patterns throughout its eight-legged form. The composition splits into four quadrants around the creature, each showing extreme conditions: deep space's starry void with harsh radiation beams (purple and ultraviolet), crackling ice crystals in electric blue representing near-absolute zero, searing orange flames for extreme heat, and a cosmic radiation burst in green. The style should blend photorealistic scientific detail with a touch of the surreal, using dramatic chiaroscuro lighting that makes the tardigrade appear both vulnerable and indestructible, with its internal structures—including the crystallized trehalose replacing water—visible through its semi-transparent cuticle like stained glass catching light.

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory. Scientists discovered in 2021 that this happens because wombat intestines have varying elasticity in different regions, with stiff and soft sections that mold the poop into cubes during the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to varying intestinal elasticity that forms the shape in the final 8% of the intestine, and they do use these cubes to mark territory.
facts.image_description: A scientific cross-section illustration showing a wombat in profile with a semi-transparent view of its distinctive intestinal tract, rendered in warm earth tones of browns and soft pinks against a muted eucalyptus green background. The intestines are depicted with alternating bands of deep rose (stiff sections) and pale pink (elastic sections), with small arrows indicating the gradual transformation of waste from cylindrical to cubic shapes in the final portion. In the foreground, a small stack of precisely geometric, dark brown cube-shaped droppings sits on sun-dappled Australian soil scattered with dried grass, while the wombat's fuzzy, stocky body is rendered in rich sepia and umber tones with photorealistic fur texture. Subtle anatomical labels in clean sans-serif font mark the key intestinal regions, giving it the polished aesthetic of a nature documentary or museum display, blending educational clarity with engaging visual storytelling.

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory. Scientists discovered this happens because wombat intestines have varying elasticity in different sections, with stiffer regions forming the edges and softer regions forming the faces of the cubes as the digestive muscles contract.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to differential stiffness in their intestinal walls creating flat sides and sharp corners during the final stages of digestion, and they do use these cubes to mark territory by stacking them on elevated surfaces.
facts.image_description: The illustration shows a cross-sectional scientific diagram in warm earth tones, depicting a wombat's digestive tract in translucent amber and pink hues against a soft eucalyptus-green background. The intestinal walls are rendered in detailed anatomical style with color-coded regions—deep burgundy indicating stiffer, less elastic sections that form cube edges, and pale rose showing softer, more pliable areas that create the flat faces. Directional arrows in golden yellow demonstrate the rhythmic muscular contractions, while a sequence of forming feces gradually transforms from rounded to distinctly cubic shapes along the intestinal path. In the corner, a small inset shows a proud wombat stacking its geometric droppings on a rock, rendered in gentle watercolor style to contrast with the technical precision of the main anatomical illustration.

facts.text: Tardigrades, microscopic animals also known as water bears, can survive being frozen to almost absolute zero (-272°C), heated to 150°C, exposed to the vacuum of space, and blasted with radiation levels that would kill most life forms. When conditions become inhospitable, they expel nearly all water from their bodies and enter a death-like state called cryptobiosis, where they can remain for decades before springing back to life when rehydrated.
facts.verification_note: Tardigrades have been scientifically documented to survive extreme temperatures (from near absolute zero to 150°C), space vacuum exposure, high radiation doses, and can enter cryptobiosis by desiccating to ~3% water content, remaining viable for decades until rehydration.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a large, translucent tardigrade as the central figure, rendered in a semi-photorealistic style with scientific accuracy, showing its eight stubby legs, clawed feet, and segmented body in pale blues and translucent whites against a split background. The left half should show the tardigrade in its active, hydrated state surrounded by water droplets with soft, luminous lighting, while the right half depicts it in cryptobiosis—shriveled, crystalline, and glowing faintly amber—surrounded by extreme environment symbols: ice crystals, flames, stars representing the vacuum of space, and stylized radiation waves in electric greens and purples. Small circular vignettes in the corners should illustrate the extreme conditions it survives: a thermometer showing -272°C, another at 150°C, a radiation hazard symbol, and Earth viewed from space. The overall composition should balance scientific precision with dramatic visual storytelling, using a dark cosmic background that transitions from deep space black to laboratory white, emphasizing the tardigrade's remarkable resilience through glowing bioluminescent accents and sharp contrast between the two states.

    <ellipse cx="15" cy="0" rx="8" ry="12" fill="#5098d0" opacity="0.3"/>

  <!-- Crypto Tardigrade (right side) -->

    <!-- Contracted head -->

    <!-- Contracted legs -->

      <path d="M -30 12 Q -32 20 -33 25" stroke="#a87844" stroke-width="5" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
      <circle cx="-33" cy="25" r="2.5" fill="#886030"/>

      <path d="M 25 12 Q 28 20 30 25" stroke="#a87844" stroke-width="5" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
      <circle cx="30" cy="25" r="2.5" fill="#886030"/>
      
      <path d="M -30 -12 Q -32 -20 -33 -25" stroke="#a87844" stroke-width="4" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round" opacity="0.6"/>
      <path d="M -12 -15 Q -12 -23 -12 -28" stroke="#a87844" stroke-width="4" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round" opacity="0.6"/>
      <path d="M 8 -15 Q 10 -23 11 -28" stroke="#a87844" stroke-width="4" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round" opacity="0.6"/>
      <path d="M 25 -12 Q 28 -20 30 -25" stroke="#a87844" stroke-width="4" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round" opacity="0.6"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Crystalline texture -->
    <path d="M -10 -5 L 0 -10 L 10 -5 L 10 5 L 0 10 L -10 5 Z" fill="none" stroke="#ffcc88" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.4"/>
    <path d="M -20 0 L -15 -8 M 15 -8 L 20 0 M -15 8 L -20 0 M 20 0 L 15 8" stroke="#ffcc88" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.3"/>
    
    <!-- Glow effect -->

      <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0.5;0.8;0.5" dur="3s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </ellipse>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Corner vignettes -->
  <!-- Top-left: Cold temperature -->
  <g transform="translate(60, 60)">
    <circle cx="0" cy="0" r="35" fill="#1a2a4a" opacity="0.8"/>
    <rect x="-8" y="-20" width="16" height="35" rx="8" fill="none" stroke="#4080c0" stroke-width="2"/>

  </g>
  
  <!-- Top-right: Hot temperature -->

  </g>
  
  <!-- Bottom-right: Space/Earth -->

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory and prevent them from rolling away. Scientists discovered in 2021 that this happens because wombat intestines have regions of varying elasticity that mold the poop into cubes during the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces through varying intestinal elasticity in the final portion of digestion, and they do stack these cubes as territorial markers that resist rolling.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional scientific diagram in a clean, educational style showing a wombat's digestive system in warm browns and soft pinks, with the intestinal tract highlighted and labeled to show the varying elasticity regions that form the cubic shape. In the foreground, a photorealistic wombat stands beside a small stack of its distinctive cube-shaped droppings in earthy browns, arranged like building blocks on Australian red soil dotted with native grasses. The lighting should be natural and bright, reminiscent of golden hour, with an inset magnified view showing the intestinal walls at different tension points, illustrated with gradient colors from red (high elasticity) to blue (low elasticity). Small arrows and percentage markers ("92% complete" to "100%") should trace the transformation from rounded to cubic form, making the scientific process visually clear and engaging.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <linearGradient id="skyGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#87CEEB;stop-opacity:1" />

    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="groundGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#C85A3D;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#A0442F;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="wombatFur" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#6B4423;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#8B6A47;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#5A3A1F;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="intestineGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#FF6B6B;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#FFB366;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#6B9BD1;stop-opacity:0.8" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="cubeShade" cx="30%" cy="30%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#8B6F47;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#5A4A2F;stop-opacity:1" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <filter id="shadow">
      <feGaussianBlur in="SourceAlpha" stdDeviation="3"/>
      <feOffset dx="2" dy="2" result="offsetblur"/>
      <feComponentTransfer>
        <feFuncA type="linear" slope="0.3"/>
      </feComponentTransfer>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- Background -->
  <rect width="800" height="600" fill="url(#skyGradient)"/>
  
  <!-- Ground -->
  <ellipse cx="400" cy="550" rx="450" ry="100" fill="url(#groundGradient)"/>
  <rect x="0" y="500" width="800" height="100" fill="url(#groundGradient)"/>
  
  <!-- Grass elements -->

  <!-- Digestive System Diagram (Background) -->

  <circle cx="240" cy="200" r="8" fill="#FFB366"/>
  <circle cx="280" cy="240" r="8" fill="#6B9BD1"/>
  <circle cx="320" cy="280" r="8" fill="#4A7BA7"/>
  
  <!-- Arrows showing progression -->
  <path d="M 140 140 L 160 150" stroke="#333" stroke-width="2" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
  <polygon points="160,150 155,147 155,153" fill="#333"/>
  
  <path d="M 220 180 L 240 190" stroke="#333" stroke-width="2"/>

  <path d="M 260 220 L 280 230" stroke="#333" stroke-width="2"/>

  <!-- Percentage markers -->
  <circle cx="200" cy="130" r="15" fill="#FFE5CC" stroke="#333" stroke-width="2"/>
  <text x="200" y="135" text-anchor="middle" font-size="10" fill="#333" font-weight="bold">92%</text>
  
  <circle cx="280" cy="210" r="15" fill="#FFE5CC" stroke="#333" stroke-width="2"/>
  <text x="280" y="215" text-anchor="middle" font-size="10" fill="#333" font-weight="bold">96%</text>
  
  <circle cx="340" cy="290" r="15" fill="#FFE5CC" stroke="#333" stroke-width="2"/>
  <text x="340" y="295" text-anchor="middle" font-size="10" fill="#333" font-weight="bold">100%</text>
  
  <!-- Shape transformation visualization -->
  <circle cx="150" cy="300" r="12" fill="#E8B896" stroke="#333" stroke-width="1.5"/>
  <rect x="213" y="288" width="24" height="24" rx="4" fill="#D4A574" stroke="#333" stroke-width="1.5"/>
  <rect x="293" y="288" width="24" height="24" rx="1" fill="#C89968" stroke="#333" stroke-width="1.5"/>
  
  <!-- Magnified inset view -->
  <rect x="230" y="80" width="150" height="100" rx="5" fill="white" stroke="#666" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.95"/>
  
  <!-- Intestinal wall cross-section -->
  <ellipse cx="305" cy="120" rx="50" ry="30" fill="#FFD6E8" stroke="#FF6B6B" stroke-width="2"/>
  <path d="M 280 120 Q 305 110 330 120" stroke="#FF6B6B" stroke-width="4" fill="none"/>
  <path d="M 280 130 Q 305 140 330 130" stroke="#6B9BD1" stroke-width="4" fill="none"/>
  
  <!-- Tension indicators -->

  <line x1="340" y1="115" x2="350" y2="105" stroke="#FF6B6B" stroke-width="2"/>

  <!-- Realistic Wombat -->

    <ellipse cx="-75" cy="-48" rx="10" ry="14" fill="#D4A574"/>
    <ellipse cx="-45" cy="-48" rx="10" ry="14" fill="#D4A574"/>
    
    <!-- Nose -->
    <ellipse cx="-85" cy="-10" rx="12" ry="10" fill="#4A3A2F"/>
    
    <!-- Eye -->

    <circle cx="-68" cy="-26" r="2" fill="white"/>
    
    <!-- Legs -->
    <ellipse cx="-50" cy="40" rx="18" ry="30" fill="#6B4423"/>
    <ellipse cx="-10" cy="45" rx="18" ry="30" fill="#6B4423"/>
    <ellipse cx="30" cy="45" rx="18" ry="30" fill="#5A3A1F"/>
    <ellipse cx="60" cy="40" rx="18" ry="28" fill="#5A3A1F"/>
    
    <!-- Paws -->
    <ellipse cx="-50" cy="65" rx="15" ry="8" fill="#4A3A2F"/>
    <ellipse cx="-10" cy="70" rx="15" ry="8" fill="#4A3A2F"/>
    <ellipse cx="30" cy="70" rx="15" ry="8" fill="#3A2A1F"/>
    <ellipse cx="60" cy="65" rx="15" ry="8" fill="#3A2A1F"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Cube-shaped droppings stack -->
  <g transform="translate(620, 490)">
    <!-- Bottom cube -->
    <rect x="0" y="20" width="30" height="30" fill="url(#cubeShade)" stroke="#3A2A1F" stroke-width="1.5"/>
    <polygon points="30,20 45,10 45,40 30,50" fill="#6B5437" stroke="#3A2A1F" stroke-width="1.5"/>
    <polygon points="0,20 15,10 45,10 30,20" fill="#8B7447" stroke="#3A2A1F" stroke-width="1.5"/>

    <!-- Top cube -->

  <circle cx="200" cy="385" r="3" fill="#7A9B4F" opacity="0.6"/>
  
</svg>

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark territory and prevent them from rolling away. Scientists discovered this happens because of varying elasticity in the wombat's intestinal walls, which mold the poop into cubes during the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Research has confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to differential elasticity in their intestinal walls during the final portion of digestion, and they use these cubes to mark territory as they don't roll away.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional scientific diagram in a warm, naturalistic style showing a wombat's lower intestinal tract on the left side, with color-coded regions (pink to deep rose) highlighting the varying elasticity zones where the cube formation occurs. The right side should show a photorealistic Australian bush landscape at golden hour, featuring a wombat placing distinctive brown cube-shaped droppings on a rock or log, with several already-stacked cubes visible as territorial markers. Anatomical arrows and percentage labels (92% and 100%) should connect the intestinal diagram to the final cube product, while the background should include eucalyptus trees and native grasses in soft focus. The overall composition should blend medical textbook precision with National Geographic-quality wildlife photography, using a split-screen layout that tells both the biological mechanism and behavioral purpose in a single, cohesive image.

  <!-- Left side - Intestinal diagram -->

        stroke="#FFB6C1" stroke-width="50" fill="none" opacity="0.8"/>
  
  <!-- Color-coded regions -->

</svg>

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark territory and prevent rolling. Scientists discovered this happens because of unique elastic properties in the final 8% of their intestines, where the poop is molded into corners through varying tissue stiffness that creates flat edges instead of the typical cylindrical shape.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to varying elasticity in the last 8% of their intestines, where differential stiffness of intestinal tissue creates the distinctive cubic shape, and they do use these to mark territory.
facts.image_description: A split-panel scientific illustration shows a wombat in its natural Australian habitat on the left, rendered in warm earth tones and dappled forest lighting, depositing distinctive cube-shaped droppings on a rock or log. The right panel features a detailed cross-sectional anatomical diagram of the wombat's lower intestinal tract, with the final 8% highlighted in contrasting colors—blues and purples for areas of varying tissue elasticity—and arrows indicating how the varying stiffness zones compress and mold the waste into flat planes and sharp corners. Small inset diagrams show the progressive transformation from cylindrical to cubic shape, with labels pointing to regions of high and low elasticity. The style blends photorealistic wildlife art with clean, modern medical illustration techniques, using a muted palette of browns, greens, and clinical blues against a cream background, making the unusual biological mechanism both scientifically accurate and visually captivating.

facts.text: When a caterpillar transforms into a butterfly, it literally digests itself into a protein-rich soup inside its chrysalis, with nearly all of its body breaking down into cellular mush. Only a few clusters of cells called "imaginal discs" survive this process and use the soup to build the entirely new body of the butterfly.
facts.verification_note: During metamorphosis, caterpillar tissues do undergo histolysis (breaking down into a nutrient-rich fluid) while imaginal discs, which existed in the larva, use these resources to develop into adult butterfly structures.
facts.image_description: A cross-sectional scientific illustration shows a translucent chrysalis split vertically down the middle, revealing the metamorphosis in progress: the left half displays the dissolving caterpillar body rendered as swirling, luminescent green-gold protein soup with fragmenting tissue structures, while the right half shows glowing clusters of imaginal discs—small, jewel-like cellular nodes in deep amber and violet—floating in the organic fluid and beginning to organize into the delicate wing structures and body segments of an emerging butterfly. The illustration uses a dark, deep blue-black background to make the bioluminescent quality of the transformation pop, with cutaway anatomical labels and fine stippled shading in the style of vintage natural history engravings combined with modern scientific visualization. Wisps of dissolving caterpillar tissue drift through the soup like nebulae, while the imaginal discs pulse with an inner light, connected by faint threads of organizing cells that hint at the butterfly's future form—antennae, compound eyes, and gossamer wings beginning to take shape in ghostly outline.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <radialGradient id="bgGradient" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="70%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#0a1628;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#000508;stop-opacity:1" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="soupGlow" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#d4ff00;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="40%" style="stop-color:#7fb800;stop-opacity:0.6" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#3d5a00;stop-opacity:0.2" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="discGlow1" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffb347;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#ff7f00;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#8b4000;stop-opacity:0.3" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="discGlow2" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#da70d6;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#8b008b;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#4b0082;stop-opacity:0.3" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="chrysalisGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#4a5568;stop-opacity:0.4" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#2d3748;stop-opacity:0.3" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#1a202c;stop-opacity:0.5" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <filter id="glow">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="3" result="coloredBlur"/>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
    
    <filter id="strongGlow">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="5" result="coloredBlur"/>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- Background -->
  <rect width="800" height="600" fill="url(#bgGradient)"/>

  <!-- Left side: Dissolving caterpillar soup -->
  <g opacity="0.9" filter="url(#glow)">

    <ellipse cx="250" cy="300" rx="110" ry="180" fill="url(#soupGlow)" opacity="0.6"/>

          stroke="#b8e600" stroke-width="8" fill="none" opacity="0.7" stroke-linecap="round"/>
    <path d="M 280 180 Q 260 220, 270 260 Q 280 300, 260 340 Q 270 380, 280 420" 
          stroke="#8fb800" stroke-width="6" fill="none" opacity="0.6" stroke-linecap="round"/>
    
    <!-- Fragmenting tissue blobs -->

  <!-- Right side: Imaginal discs and forming butterfly -->

  <!-- Connecting threads between discs -->

    <line x1="545" y1="350" x2="570" y2="390" stroke="#cc88cc" stroke-width="1.5"/>

  <!-- Emerging butterfly ghostly outline -->

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory and prevent the droppings from rolling away. Scientists discovered in 2021 that this happens because wombat intestines have varying elasticity in different regions, with stiffer sections molding the poop into corners during the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to varying intestinal elasticity that forms corners in the final portion of the intestine, and they do use these distinctive droppings to mark territory on rocks and logs where round feces would roll off.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional scientific diagram in a clean, educational style with a warm Australian outback backdrop at golden hour. The main focus is a transparent anatomical view of a wombat's digestive system, showing the intestinal tract with color-coded regions—softer pink areas transitioning to darker purple-blue stiffer sections where the distinctive cube formation occurs. In the foreground, a realistic wombat is positioned near a small stack of precisely rendered cube-shaped droppings on ochre-colored earth and scattered eucalyptus leaves, with detailed arrows and percentage markers (highlighting the final 8% zone) connecting the anatomical diagram to the physical result. The composition balances scientific accuracy with engaging visual storytelling, using a split-screen effect that shows both the internal biological mechanism and the external behavioral outcome in rich, naturalistic colors with subtle backlighting to emphasize the unique geometric shapes.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">

    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="intestineEnd" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">

    <!-- Backlighting effect -->

  </defs>

  <ellipse cx="650" cy="525" rx="24" ry="8" fill="#8BAA7A" opacity="0.7" transform="rotate(-10 650 525)"/>
  
  <!-- Split screen divider line (subtle) -->
  <line x1="400" y1="100" x2="400" y2="500" stroke="#FFFFFF" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.3" stroke-dasharray="5,5"/>
  
  <!-- LEFT SIDE: Anatomical diagram -->
  <!-- Transparent wombat body outline -->
  <ellipse cx="200" cy="280" rx="120" ry="90" fill="#8B7355" opacity="0.2" stroke="#654321" stroke-width="2"/>
  <circle cx="150" cy="240" r="45" fill="#8B7355" opacity="0.2" stroke="#654321" stroke-width="2"/>
  
  <!-- Digestive system - curved intestinal path -->
  <!-- Start section (pink) -->
  <path d="M 180 200 Q 150 220 160 250 Q 170 280 190 290" 
        fill="none" stroke="url(#intestineStart)" stroke-width="18" stroke-linecap="round"/>
  
  <!-- Middle section (pink to purple) -->
  <path d="M 190 290 Q 210 300 220 320 Q 230 340 210 360" 
        fill="none" stroke="url(#intestineMiddle)" stroke-width="18" stroke-linecap="round"/>
  
  <!-- End section (purple-blue, stiffer) -->
  <path d="M 210 360 Q 190 380 200 400 Q 210 420 230 430" 
        fill="none" stroke="url(#intestineEnd)" stroke-width="20" stroke-linecap="round"/>
  
  <!-- Final 8% zone highlight -->
  <ellipse cx="215" cy="415" rx="35" ry="25" fill="none" stroke="#FFD700" stroke-width="3" stroke-dasharray="4,2"/>
  <circle cx="215" cy="415" r="40" fill="url(#backlight)"/>
  
  <!-- Percentage marker circle -->
  <circle cx="260" cy="400" r="20" fill="#FFD700" opacity="0.9"/>
  <text x="260" y="407" font-family="Arial, sans-serif" font-size="16" font-weight="bold" fill="#654321" text-anchor="middle">8%</text>
  
  <!-- Arrow from intestine to cubes -->
  <path d="M 230 430 Q 300 460 360 480" fill="none" stroke="#654321" stroke-width="3" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
  <defs>
    <marker id="arrowhead" markerWidth="10" markerHeight="10" refX="9" refY="3" orient="auto">
      <polygon points="0 0, 10 3, 0 6" fill="#654321"/>
    </marker>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- RIGHT SIDE: Wombat and cube droppings -->
  <!-- Realistic wombat -->
  <!-- Body -->
  <ellipse cx="550" cy="380" rx="80" ry="55" fill="#6B5644"/>
  <ellipse cx="550" cy="380" rx="75" ry="50" fill="#8B7355"/>
  
  <!-- Head -->

  <!-- Ears -->

  <!-- Nose -->

  <ellipse cx="560" cy="425" rx="18" ry="25" fill="#6B5644"/>
  <ellipse cx="590" cy="420" rx="16" ry="22" fill="#6B5644"/>
  
  <!-- Cube-shaped droppings stack -->
  <!-- Shadow under cubes -->
  <ellipse cx="500" cy="495" rx="50" ry="8" fill="url(#cubeShadow)"/>
  
  <!-- Bottom cube -->
  <g transform="translate(480, 460)">

    <!-- Top face -->

    <polygon points="0,20 15,10 45,10 30,20" fill="#7A6A4F"/>

  </g>
  
  <!-- Top cube -->
  <g transform="translate(475, 400)">
    <polygon points="0,20 30,20 30,50 0,50" fill="#5D4E37"/>
    <polygon points="0,20 15,10 45,10 30,20" fill="#7A6A4F"/>
    <polygon points="30,20 45,10 45,40 30,50" fill="#4A3C28"/>
    <line x1="0" y1="20" x2="15" y2="10" stroke="#8B7D5F" stroke-width="1"/>
    <line x1="15" y1="10" x2="45" y2="10" stroke="#8B7D5F" stroke-width="1"/>

  </g>
  
  <!-- Backlighting around cubes -->

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark their territory and prevent them from rolling away. Scientists discovered this happens because the final 8% of their intestine has varying elasticity, with stiff and flexible sections that mold the poop into cubes over several days of digestion.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2018-2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to varying elasticity in the final 8% of their intestines, with alternating stiff and flexible regions that shape the feces into cubes, which they use for territorial marking on elevated surfaces where the cubic shape prevents rolling.
facts.image_description: A split-panel scientific illustration showing a cross-section of a wombat's digestive system on the left, with the final 8% of the intestine highlighted in contrasting colors—stiff sections in deep burgundy and flexible sections in soft pink—demonstrating how the varying elasticity molds the feces into cubic shapes through a series of progressive stages. The right panel depicts a photorealistic wombat in golden-hour lighting on Australian bushland, deliberately stacking glossy, dark brown cube-shaped droppings on a rock or log, with previously placed cubes visible in the background showing their geometric precision. The illustration uses warm earth tones throughout, with anatomical labels in clean sans-serif font, and includes a magnified inset showing the cellular structure of the intestinal walls with arrows indicating compression patterns that create the cube's distinctive edges and corners.
